question: A patient, aged 44, presented with a complex medical background, including HIV and history of Kaposi's Sarcoma. Notably, he was diagnosed with Ebstein's anomaly, a rare congenital heart defect. This condition resulted in significant morphological changes in his right heart structures. His post-operative health was complicated by low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS), necessitating advanced life support.Based on the patient's clinical presentation, what are the characteristic features of Ebstein's anomaly?
options: {'A': 'left ventricular hypertrophy with mitral valve stenosis.', 'B': 'pulmonary hypertension with severe pulmonary valve stenosis.', 'C': 'increased pulmonary vascular resistance with right ventricular hypertrophy.', 'D': 'right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, and moderate ventricular dysfunction.', 'E': 'left atrial and left ventricular dilatation, moderate aortic regurgitation.'}
answer: right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, and moderate ventricular dysfunction.

clinical_note:
A 62-year-old man, affected dysphagia, was endoscopically diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer confirmed squamous cell carcinoma on biopsy, and was reffered to our hospital (Fig. ). He had no medical history. His lifestyle has included 1500 ml beer consumption per day and 40 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. Computed tomography (CT) showed thickening of the wall in the lower esophagus as the primary lesion was demonstrated and the tumor formed a mass with the solitary metastatic abdominal lymph node, and invaded pancreas body and gastric body (Fig. ). No other distant metastasis was detected on CT. He was diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer cT4 N1 M0, with pancreatic invasion, cStage IIIC according to 7th edition of the Union for International Cancer Control system []. At first, we considered definitive chemoradiotherapy. However, radiation oncologists evaluated that the tumor was less candidate for chemoradiotherapy because of the risk of gastric mucosal damage. For the purpose of definitive therapy, radical esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy was planned. As neoadjuvant chemotherapy, CF therapy (cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil therapy; cisplatin was dripped 80 mg/m2 plus 5-fluorouracil was infused 800 mg/m2 on day 1 through 4 continuously) was started according to standard therapy of localized advanced esophageal cancer []. However, after once administration, he could not continue chemotherapy for the exacerbation of dysphagia, and underwent radical surgery. Preoperative evaluation of tumor was similar to initial findings on endoscopy and CT.
In findings on laparotomy, abdominal lymph node was infiltrated directly to pancreas body. As the radical surgery, Ivor Lewis esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy, followed by reconstruction of gastric conduit. Two fields lymphadenectomy was performed according to the treatment strategy of the abdominal esophageal cancer. Reconstruction of gastric conduit was possible although the lymph node was adherent to lesser side of gastric body, which was resected when reconstruction of gastric conduit. In addition, partial resection of lung was performed simultaneously owing to involvement of bilateral pulmonary ligaments to the primary tumor (Fig. ). The operative time was 528 min. The estimated blood loss was 2850 ml, and the patient was transfused 4 units of red blood cell concentrates.
The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was able to take orally. He was discharged 16 days after operation with tube-free. After discharge, he underwent two courses of CF therapy as adjuvant chemotherapy. At present, he is still alive and has no recurrence for 7 years after surgery.
In the resected specimen, the primary lesion was observed from lower esophagus to esophagogastric junction, and metastatic lymph node was fixed to stomach and pancreas body (Fig. ). Pathological examination revealed that primary lesion was not infiltrated to lung (Fig. a, b). Massive metastatic lymph node (over 5cm) was observed in the lesser curvature of stomach, and infiltrated to pancreas and gastric wall with extranodal extension (Fig. c, d). The tumor was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated type. The vascular and lymphatic invasion was confirmed. The surgical margin was negative. The pathological stage was ypT4 N1 (1/61) M0 (metastatic lymph node invasion into pancreas), ypStage IIIC. The histopathological response of chemotherapy was grade 1a, which was equivalent that proliferable cells were 2/3 or more, in 7th edition of the Union for International Cancer Control system [].
topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: A 62-year-old man, diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer, was referred to our hospital following confirmation of a squamous cell carcinoma via endoscopy and biopsy. The patient had no significant medical history but has been a heavy drinker and smoker for the past 40 years. CT scans revealed a thickened wall in the lower esophagus, a solitary metastatic abdominal lymph node, and invasion into the pancreas and gastric body. Initially, definitive chemoradiotherapy was considered, but due to the risk of damage to the gastric mucosa, radical esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy was planned. He was started on neoadjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin (80 mg/m2) and 5-fluorouracil (800 mg/m2), a standard therapy for localized advanced esophageal cancer. However, after one administration, his dysphagia worsened, halting the chemotherapy and leading to the decision of radical surgery. The patient successfully underwent an Ivor Lewis esophagectomy, distal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and reconstruction of the gastric conduit. Post-surgery, he was able to eat orally and was discharged after 16 days. He then underwent two courses of the same chemotherapy regimen as adjuvant therapy. Presently, he remains alive and recurrence-free seven years post-surgery. Pathological examination confirmed squamous cell carcinoma, moderate differentiation, vascular and lymphatic invasion, and a negative surgical margin. The tumor was classified as ypT4 N1 M0, ypStage IIIC.What is the mechanism of action of cisplatin in the treatment of squamous cell carcinoma?
options: {'A': 'Cisplatin forms platinum-DNA adducts that cause DNA damage and inhibit DNA replication, leading to cell death.', 'B': 'Cisplatin inhibits microtubule polymerization, disrupting cell division', 'C': 'Cisplatin inhibits folic acid metabolism, disrupting DNA synthesis', 'D': 'Cisplatin inhibits the enzyme tyrosine kinase, disrupting cell signaling', 'E': 'Cisplatin inhibits topoisomerase II, leading to DNA strand breaks', 'F': 'Cisplatin inhibits RNA polymerase, disrupting RNA synthesis.'}
answer: Cisplatin forms platinum-DNA adducts that cause DNA damage and inhibit DNA replication, leading to cell death.

question: A 62-year-old man, with a lifestyle that includes heavy alcohol consumption (around 1500 ml beer per day) and smoking (40 cigarettes per day) for the past 40 years, was diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer that had metastasized to an abdominal lymph node and invaded the pancreas body and gastric body. Despite the severity of his condition, he has remained free of cancer for 7 years post-surgery.Which lifestyle habits of the patient have potentially contributed to his lower esophageal cancer?
options: {'A': 'sedentary lifestyle', 'B': 'high intake of processed foods', 'C': 'obesity', 'D': 'low fruit and vegetable intake', 'E': 'heavy alcohol consumption and smoking'}

topic: select most appropriate laboratory or diagnostic study
question: A 62-year-old man with a history of heavy alcohol and tobacco use was diagnosed with lower esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor has invaded the pancreas and gastric body, and a single metastatic abdominal lymph node was found. The patient was staged as cT4 N1 M0, cStage IIIC. Due to the potential risk of gastric mucosal damage, definitive chemoradiotherapy was ruled out. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy was discontinued due to exacerbation of dysphagia, leading to the decision for surgical intervention.Which diagnostic study is most appropriate for further staging of this patient's lower esophageal squamous cell carcinoma following esophagogastroduodenoscopy?
options: {'A': 'barium swallow', 'B': 'endoscopic ultrasound', 'C': 'pet scan', 'D': 'ct chest and abdomen with iv contrast', 'E': 'mri of the abdomen', 'F': 'colonoscopy'}
answer: ct chest and abdomen with iv contrast

question: A 62-year-old male with a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption presented with dysphagia. Endoscopic examination and biopsy results confirmed the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in the lower esophagus. The CT scan revealed tumor invasion into the pancreas and gastric body with a solitary metastatic abdominal lymph node. The patient underwent an esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy after initial chemotherapy. Postoperative pathological findings pointed towards a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with vascular and lymphatic invasion. Seven years after surgery, the patient remains recurrence-free.What type of esophageal cancer does the pathological findings suggest in this patient?
options: {'A': 'well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with lymphatic invasion', 'B': 'poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma without lymphatic invasion', 'C': 'poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with vascular and lymphatic invasion', 'D': 'moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with vascular and lymphatic invasion', 'E': 'moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with vascular invasion', 'F': 'well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma without vascular invasion'}
answer: moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with vascular and lymphatic invasion

topic: select most likely diagnosis
question: A 62-year-old male patient, with no significant medical history, presented with dysphagia. He had a lifestyle history of heavy beer consumption and smoking. Upon investigation, a mass was identified in the lower part of his esophagus and was confirmed to be squamous cell carcinoma through biopsy. CT scans showed the primary lesion invading the pancreas and gastric body, with no distant metastasis detected. The patient underwent radical esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy as part of his treatment. The post-operative pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma with vascular and lymphatic invasion.After considering the patient's symptoms, lifestyle history, and the results of the biopsy and CT scans, what is the most probable diagnosis?
options: {'A': 'gastroesophageal junction cancer', 'B': 'gastric cancer', 'C': 'esophageal leiomyosarcoma', 'D': 'pancreatic cancer', 'E': 'squamous cell carcinoma of the lower esophagus', 'F': 'adenocarcinoma of the lower esophagus'}
answer: squamous cell carcinoma of the lower esophagus

topic: recognizes associated conditions of a disease
question: A 62-year-old man with a history of significant alcohol and tobacco use was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower esophagus, presenting with dysphagia. CT imaging revealed thickening of the lower esophageal wall and a mass formed by the primary lesion and a solitary metastatic abdominal lymph node, invading the body of the pancreas and stomach. No other distant metastases were detected. He was initially considered for chemoradiotherapy, but due to the risk of gastric mucosal damage, a radical esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy was planned. However, due to worsening of dysphagia, neoadjuvant chemotherapy was only partially completed before the radical surgery was performed. During the surgery, the abdomen lymph node was found to be directly infiltrating the pancreas body. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was able to ingest orally. He was discharged 16 days after operation without need for feeding tube. He then underwent two courses of CF therapy as adjuvant chemotherapy and has remained recurrence-free for 7 years post-surgery. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen revealed a massive metastatic lymph node in the lesser curvature of the stomach, infiltrating the pancreas and gastric wall, and confirmed the presence of vascular and lymphatic invasion. The pathological stage was ypT4 N1 (1/61) M0, ypStage IIIC. The response to chemotherapy was grade 1a, indicating that proliferable cells were 2/3 or more.What is a potential complication of squamous cell carcinoma of the lower esophagus?
options: {'A': 'Acute pancreatitis', 'B': 'Appendicitis', 'C': 'Kidney stones', 'D': 'Gastric ulcers', 'E': 'Esophageal stenosis', 'F': 'Gallstones', 'G': 'Hepatitis'}

topic: Knows adverse effects of various drugs or recognizes signs and symptoms of drug (and drug-drug) interactions
question: A 62-year-old man with a history of heavy beer consumption and cigarette smoking was diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer, confirmed as squamous cell carcinoma on biopsy. The primary lesion was located in the lower esophagus, with metastasis to a solitary abdominal lymph node, and invasion of the pancreas and gastric body. No other distant metastasis was detected. Initial treatment consideration was definitive chemoradiotherapy, but due to the risk of gastric mucosal damage, radical esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy was planned. The patient was given neoadjuvant chemotherapy with CF therapy (cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil). However, due to an exacerbation of dysphagia, the patient could only undergo one administration before surgery was required. Post-operative recovery was uneventful, and the patient was able to resume oral intake. He was discharged 16 days after the operation and underwent two rounds of CF therapy as adjuvant chemotherapy. Seven years after surgery, the patient remains alive and without recurrence.What are the potential side effects of cisplatin, used in the treatment of this patient's squamous cell carcinoma?
options: {'A': 'Hepatotoxicity', 'B': 'Cardiotoxicity', 'C': 'Hemolytic anemia', 'D': 'Nephrotoxicity, Ototoxicity', 'E': 'Pulmonary fibrosis'}

clinical_note:
A 65-year-old gentleman with no comorbidities presented with progressive jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss since 4 to 5 weeks. He had no similar complaints in past. His clinical examination apart from icterus was normal. Investigations revealed a direct hyperbilirubinemia of 3.3 mg/dL. Ultrasound revealed a hypoechoic lesion in head of pancreas 3 cm × 3 cm in size with dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radical dilatation.
A pancreatic protocol contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan was performed which confirmed the ultrasound findings as shown in
. In addition to this, it showed a replaced right hepatic artery arising from superior mesenteric artery (SMA) as shown in
, and a reversal of relationship of superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and SMA, that is, the artery to the right of vein was seen as shown in
. The complete vascular anatomy is schematically shown in
. The duodenojejunal flexure was in midline. There was no significant lymphadenopathy, no liver lesions, and no free fluid. These findings were suggestive of pancreatic head adenocarcinoma with incomplete intestinal rotation and an rRHA arising from SMA. Carbohydrate antigen 19–9 (CA 19–9) was elevated at 196 U/mL (normal: < 37 U/mL) and Carcinoembryonic antigen was normal. A pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy was planned for the patient.
During surgery, the small bowel loops were found clumped in right upper abdomen and a Kocher's maneuver was carefully performed after interbowel adhesiolysis to free all the loops till the third part of duodenum. SMA and SMV were then identified and looped at the lower border of pancreas. Hepatoduodenal ligament dissection was then performed to identify the replaced right hepatic artery and the main portal vein. The retropancreatic tunnel was created in a plane above the portal vein superiorly and the SMA inferiorly, and then the plane was widened till the area above SMV (
). Uncinate dissection, duodenojejunal flexure mobilization, and standard lymphadenectomy were then performed, followed by division of jejunum, first part of duodenum common bile duct and pancreas. The vascular relations can be seen after resection completion in
.
Reconstruction was performed as the modified Blumgart technique of duct to mucosa pancreatico-jejunostomy with 5–0 polypropylene, single layer interrupted hepatico jejunostomy using 4–0 polypropylene and antecolic stapled posterior gastrojejunostomy. The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged on the postoperative day 8. Histopathological examination showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma confined to pancreas with all margins free and single peripancreatic node out of 18 was positive. question: A 65-year-old gentleman with no prior health conditions presented with symptoms of progressive jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss for the past 4-5 weeks. His medical investigations showed a direct hyperbilirubinemia of 3.3 mg/dL and an ultrasound revealed a hypoechoic lesion in the head of his pancreas, approximately 3 cm x 3 cm in size. Further ultrasound findings included a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radical dilatation. A pancreatic protocol contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan confirmed these findings. The patient had no significant lymphadenopathy, liver lesions, or free fluid. These findings were indicative of pancreatic head adenocarcinoma. The patient's Carbohydrate antigen 19–9 (CA 19–9) levels were elevated, indicating the possibility of pancreatic cancer. He underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy. Post-surgery, the patient recovered without complications. Histopathological examination confirmed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma confined to the pancreas. The patient was doing well at 4-month follow up on adjuvant 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy. No mention of smoking, the strongest exogenous risk factor of pancreatic cancer, was made in the patient's history.What is the strongest exogenous risk factor for pancreatic cancer, which is not mentioned in the patient's history?
options: {'A': 'Advanced age.', 'B': 'Obesity', 'C': 'Smoking', 'D': 'Alcohol consumption', 'E': 'Chronic pancreatitis', 'F': 'High fat diet', 'G': 'Diabetes mellitus', 'H': 'Genetic predisposition'}

question: A 65-year-old man with no prior medical conditions presented with a progressive yellowing of the skin (jaundice), loss of appetite (anorexia), and weight loss over the past month. He had no previous similar health complaints. His physical examination was unremarkable aside from the jaundice. Laboratory tests showed a high concentration of bilirubin in his blood (hyperbilirubinemia), suggesting a problem with his liver or bile duct. An ultrasound revealed a hypoechoic (dark) lesion in the head of his pancreas, measuring 3 cm × 3 cm, and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radical dilatation. These findings were confirmed by a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan, which also revealed an unusual arterial formation in his liver and a reversal in the positioning of his superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and superior mesenteric artery (SMA). The patient's carbohydrate antigen 19–9 (CA 19–9), a biomarker for pancreatic cancer, was elevated, further suggesting a diagnosis of pancreatic head adenocarcinoma. A pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy, a surgical procedure to remove the head of the pancreas, was planned for the patient. The surgery was performed successfully and the patient was discharged on the eighth postoperative day. Histopathological examination of the removed tissue confirmed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma confined to the pancreas. The patient is currently doing well four months post-surgery and is undergoing adjuvant 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.What is the likely diagnosis for a 65-year-old man presenting with jaundice, anorexia, weight loss, and a hypoechoic lesion in the head of his pancreas along with elevated levels of carbohydrate antigen 19-9?
options: {'A': 'Cholangiocarcinoma', 'B': 'Gastric cancer', 'C': 'Hepatocellular carcinoma', 'D': 'Gallbladder cancer', 'E': 'Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor', 'F': 'Chronic pancreatitis', 'G': 'Pancreatic head adenocarcinoma'}

question: A 65-year-old male with no past medical history presented with jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss over the past month. His physical examination was largely unremarkable, except for icterus. Lab results showed direct hyperbilirubinemia. An ultrasound of the abdomen revealed a hypoechoic lesion in the head of the pancreas and dilation of the common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicals.What is the most suitable diagnostic study to further evaluate the patient's condition?
options: {'A': 'pancreatic protocol contrast-enhanced computed tomography (cect) scan', 'B': 'colonoscopy', 'C': 'endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (', 'D': 'magnetic resonance imaging (', 'E': 'abdominal x-ray'}
answer: pancreatic protocol contrast-enhanced computed tomography (cect) scan

clinical_note: In November 2016, a Caucasian 75-year-old woman, a former smoker (7.5 pack-years), was hospitalized for breathlessness. Her past medical history included atrial fibrillation treated with warfarin, arterial hypertension treated with betaloxol, and gastroesophageal reflux. She ran a bar–tobacco shop with significant long-term exposure to passive smoking. She was not exposed to asbestos. Clinical examination on admission revealed good performance status, stage 1 modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea, crackles at lung bases, and no digital clubbing or extrathoracic signs. Chest computed tomography (CT) scan showed interstitial lung disease (ILD) with subpleural reticulations without evidence of honeycombing or enlarged lymph node (Fig. ). Standard biology, serological testing, bronchoscopy, and bronchoalveolar lavage were normal. Pulmonary function tests demonstrated bronchial obstruction [forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1)/forced vital capacity (FVC) ratio, 0.66; FEV1, 97% of predicted values (% pred.)], preserved volumes [FVC, 121% pred.; total lung capacity (TLC), 111% pred.], and alteration of gas diffusion (TLCO, 62% pred.). ILD multidisciplinary discussion (MDD) reached a CT pattern of possible usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), which led to the proposal of performing surgical lung biopsy. Wedge resection of the right upper and lower lobes was performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery in July 2017. Both resected lung specimens showed a similar pattern of UIP: fibroblastic foci and honeycombing. In addition, the right lower lobe specimen displayed numerous disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive SCC without invasion of visceral pleura (Fig. ). Complete resection was obtained without SCC-positive surgical margins. A PET–CT scan performed in September 2017 showed mild hypermetabolism of ILD [maximum standardized uptake value (SUVmax), 3.5], without hypermetabolic lung nodule, mass, or enlarged lymph node. Cerebral magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was normal. There was no indication for adjuvant antineoplastic treatment based on pathological findings. After ILD MDD in October 2017, it was decided to introduce an antifibrotic treatment owing to pathological confirmation of UIP. Nintedanib was chosen as this molecule is also known for its antitumor properties. At the last follow-up in October 2019, that is, 2 years after initiation of nintedanib, clinical, functional (FVC, 130% pred.; TLCO, 61% pred.), and CT scan evaluations were stable (Fig. ). There was no evidence of squamous cell carcinoma progression.
topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: The patient, a 75-year-old woman with a history of passive smoking, presented with breathlessness. Medical investigations including chest CT scan and biopsy confirmed the diagnoses of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). An antifibrotic treatment was initiated with the drug nintedanib, known for its dual therapeutic properties. The patient's condition remained stable over the course of two years without any evidence of SCC progression.What dual therapeutic properties of the prescribed drug, nintedanib, benefited the management of this patient's condition?
options: {'A': 'nintedanib assists in regenerating damaged lung tissues in uip and scc.', 'B': 'nintedanib functions as an antifibrotic agent, slowing the progression of usual interstitial pneumonia, and has antitumor properties that aid in managing squamous cell carcinoma.', 'C': 'nintedanib enhances oxygenation in the blood, beneficial for patients with uip and scc.', 'D': 'nintedanib acts as an anti-inflammatory drug, managing inflammation in both uip and scc.', 'E': 'nintedanib suppresses the immune response, beneficial for patients dealing with uip and scc.'}
answer: nintedanib functions as an antifibrotic agent, slowing the progression of usual interstitial pneumonia, and has antitumor properties that aid in managing squamous cell carcinoma.

question: A 75-year-old former smoker woman, with a history of atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux, presented with breathlessness. Surgical lung biopsy revealed a pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). options: {'A': 'Wheezing and chest tightness', 'B': 'Breathlessness, crackles at lung bases, bronchial obstruction, and alteration of gas diffusion.', 'C': 'Chest pain and coughing up blood', 'D': 'Sudden weight loss and night sweats', 'E': 'Dry cough and fever', 'F': 'Chronic cough with yellowish-green phlegm'}
answer: Breathlessness, crackles at lung bases, bronchial obstruction, and alteration of gas diffusion.

Clinical examination on admission revealed good performance status, stage 1 modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea, crackles at lung bases, and no digital clubbing or extrathoracic signs. Chest computed tomography (CT) scan showed interstitial lung disease (ILD) with subpleural reticulations without evidence of honeycombing or enlarged lymph node (Fig. ). Standard biology, serological testing, bronchoscopy, and bronchoalveolar lavage were normal. Pulmonary function tests demonstrated bronchial obstruction [forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1)/forced vital capacity (FVC) ratio, 0.66; FEV1, 97% of predicted values (% pred.)], preserved volumes [FVC, 121% pred.; total lung capacity (TLC), 111% pred.], and alteration of gas diffusion (TLCO, 62% pred.). ILD multidisciplinary discussion (MDD) reached a CT pattern of possible usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), which led to the proposal of performing surgical lung biopsy. Wedge resection of the right upper and lower lobes was performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery in July 2017. Both resected lung specimens showed a similar pattern of UIP: fibroblastic foci and honeycombing. In addition, the right lower lobe specimen displayed numerous disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive SCC without invasion of visceral pleura (Fig. ). Complete resection was obtained without SCC-positive surgical margins. A PET–CT scan performed in September 2017 showed mild hypermetabolism of ILD [maximum standardized uptake value (SUVmax), 3.5], without hypermetabolic lung nodule, mass, or enlarged lymph node. Cerebral magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was normal. There was no indication for adjuvant antineoplastic treatment based on pathological findings. After ILD MDD in October 2017, it was decided to introduce an antifibrotic treatment owing to pathological confirmation of UIP. Nintedanib was chosen as this molecule is also known for its antitumor properties. At the last follow-up in October 2019, that is, 2 years after initiation of nintedanib, clinical, functional (FVC, 130% pred.; TLCO, 61% pred.), and CT scan evaluations were stable (Fig. ). There was no evidence of squamous cell carcinoma progression.
keypoint: possible complications of ILD (e.g. pulmonary hypertension)

question: A 75-year-old woman with a history of smoking and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation and arterial hypertension was admitted with breathlessness. Further investigation revealed she had interstitial lung disease with a pattern indicative of usual interstitial pneumonia. After pathological confirmation, she was started on an antifibrotic treatment. Interstitial lung diseases, such as the one seen in this patient, are known to be associated with certain complications.What is a possible complication that could develop in patients diagnosed with interstitial lung disease?
options: {'A': 'pulmonary hypertension', 'B': 'bronchial asthma', 'C': 'chronic bronchitis', 'D': 'emphysema', 'E': 'tuberculosis'}

question: A 75-year-old woman with a history of active and passive smoking was admitted to the hospital due to breathlessness. She had other health conditions including atrial fibrillation and arterial hypertension. Despite having quit smoking, her significant exposure to passive smoking in her workplace was of concern. A chest CT scan revealed interstitial lung disease (ILD), a condition often associated with long-term exposure to harmful tobacco smoke.What role does the patient's history of smoking and passive smoke exposure play in her present lung condition?
options: {'A': "the patient's smoking history has no significant relation to her interstitial lung disease.", 'B': 'the primary cause of her interstitial lung disease is her arterial hypertension, not her smoking history.', 'C': "the damage caused by smoking and passive smoke exposure is reversible and wouldn't result in a chronic condition like interstitial lung disease.", 'D': 'the interstitial lung disease is likely a consequence of her gastroesophageal reflux disease, not her smoking exposure.', 'E': "the patient's history of both active smoking and passive smoke exposure have likely contributed to the development of her interstitial lung disease, as these factors can cause chronic inflammation and damage to the lung tissue."}
answer: the patient's history of both active smoking and passive smoke exposure have likely contributed to the development of her interstitial lung disease, as these factors can cause chronic inflammation and damage to the lung tissue.

question: A 75-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux was admitted to the hospital for breathlessness. She was a former smoker and had long-term exposure to passive smoking from running a bar–tobacco shop. No asbestos exposure was reported. Clinical examination revealed crackles at lung bases and a CT scan showed interstitial lung disease (ILD) with subpleural reticulations. Pulmonary function tests demonstrated bronchial obstruction and alteration of gas diffusion. A surgical lung biopsy revealed a pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) and well-differentiated focally invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). There was no evidence of SCC progression. Due to the pathological confirmation of UIP, an antifibrotic treatment, specifically nintedanib, was initiated. Nintedanib was chosen for its known antitumor properties. Two years after the initiation of nintedanib, the patient's clinical, functional, and CT scan evaluations were stable.What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for a patient with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) and stable squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)?
options: {'A': 'Beta-blockers', 'B': 'Nintedanib', 'C': 'Amiodarone', 'D': 'Statins', 'E': 'Warfarin', 'F': 'Lisinopril', 'G': 'Enalapril', 'H': 'Corticosteroids'}

question: A 75-year-old woman presented with breathlessness and was diagnosed with interstitial lung disease (ILD) through a CT scan. A subsequent surgical lung biopsy revealed the presence of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Her medical history includes atrial fibrillation treated with warfarin, and she had significant exposure to passive smoking. The chosen treatment approach was Nintedanib, which is known for its antifibrotic and antitumor properties.Which therapeutic approach could potentially exacerbate the patient's condition?
options: {'A': 'use of proton pump inhibitors could exacerbate gastroesophageal reflux.', 'B': 'antifibrotic therapy could potentially worsen the interstitial lung disease.', 'C': 'immunosuppressive therapy could potentially stimulate the growth and spread of squamous cell carcinoma.', 'D': 'use of bronchodilators could lead to adverse cardiac events.', 'E': 'anticoagulation therapy could result in an increased risk of bleeding.'}
answer: immunosuppressive therapy could potentially stimulate the growth and spread of squamous cell carcinoma.

clinical_note:
A 68-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital on December 2, 2020, due to being “anxious and easily frightened for 3 months, psychomotor retardation, and affected by urinary incontinence for half a month.” The patient had no mental illness before and developed symptoms 3 months before admission. These included waking up early, being nervous and afraid for no apparent reason, and being fearful of leaving the house. The patient was upset, sensitive, and cried occasionally. In addition, the patient needed walking support (e.g., hands on the wall) at home to prevent falling. The patient had been hospitalized at a local mental health center 2 months prior to the present admission, where she was diagnosed with “GAD.” She received paroxetine (20 mg/d), tandospirone (30 mg/d), and oxazepam (15 mg/d). Her symptoms improved, and so she was discharged. She reported that she took the medications regularly according to the instructions. However, half a month prior to admission at our hospital, the patient experienced a relapse characterized by anxiety, fear, small steps while walking, reluctance to come out of her home, speaking less, and being slow to respond, as well as urinary incontinence. In addition, her social skills declined significantly, and the patient could not take care of herself independently. The patient had been diagnosed with type-II diabetes 4 years previously. No other comorbidities were reported. The patient had no abnormalities in her personal history, menstrual history, marriage and childbirth history, or family history.
Physical examination after admission revealed she had normal limb muscle strength and tone. The finger-to-nose, rapid alternating movement, heel-to-shin tests, and Romberg’s sign were normal. However, her gait was not stable and she took small steps. She was negative for pathological signs and meningeal irritation. In a psychological assessment, the patient exhibited clear consciousness, disorientation to place and time, passivity during interactions with few answers to questions, no hallucinations or delusions, a decline in memory and cognition; and a reduction in daily physical activities and energy levels. She felt distraught with a slight tremor in her hands.
Her level of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) was 6.280 µIU/mL (0.270-4.200); and she was normal for total T3, total T4, free T3, and free T4. Her level of anti-thyroglobulin antibody (anti-Tg) was 235.60 IU/mL (<115.00), and that of anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (anti-TPO) was 238.70 IU/mL (<34.00). A color Doppler ultrasound showed diffused thyroid lesions with nodular changes (nodules in the right lobe of the thyroid). Both a CT examination (Figure ) and an MRI (Figure ) of the head showed brain atrophy and leukoaraiosis. A chest CT and pelvic ultrasonography were normal. EEG recordings revealed diffuse slow waves. No epileptic activity or extreme delta brush was observed. The patient’s Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) score was 22, indicating moderate anxiety. Her Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD) score was 13, indicating a likelihood of depression. Her Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score was 14, indicating dementia.
The differential diagnosis was as follows: 1) rapidly progressive dementia, 2) type-II diabetes, and 3) subclinical hypothyroidism. After admission, the patient was treated with venlafaxine (75 mg/d) and oxazepam (15 mg/d). She showed a rapidly progressive decline in cognitive function, emotional dysregulation, paroxysmal body shaking, slow performance, abnormal gait, constipation, and urinary incontinence. However, the reason for the rapidly progressive dementia was unknown. Thus, lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid examination were performed with the following results: cerebrospinal fluid glucose: 6.30 mmol/L (2.50-4.50); protein: 0.87 g/L (0.15-0.45); and anti-glutamate receptor (NMDA) ratio: 1:3.2 (IgG).
Based on these results, the diagnosis was changed to AE. Accordingly, the patient was transferred to the neurology department and treated with immunoglobulin (IVIG, 20 g/d via intravenous infusion for 5 days) and methylprednisolone (1000 mg/d via intravenous infusion for 3 days). The dosage of methylprednisolone was dropped by half every 3 days (till 48 mg/d) and was given orally. After treatment, the patient showed a gradual recovery in cognitive and emotional function, her body shaking disappeared, and her gait was stable. Her EEG was normal. Both medications were stopped gradually. The patient was discharged 24 days after administration and had resumed a normal life without relapse at a 6-month follow-up.
keypoint: lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid examination
topic: select most appropriate laboratory or diagnostic study
question: A 68-year-old woman presented with anxiety, fear, and physical symptoms, including an unstable gait and urinary incontinence. Despite regular medication for her diagnosed Generalized Anxiety Disorder, her symptoms worsened. Along with these, she had elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone levels and anti-thyroid antibodies. Brain scans showed atrophy and leukoaraiosis. With these complex symptoms, a specific diagnostic procedure was performed to pinpoint the cause.What diagnostic procedure was instrumental in the patient's diagnosis?
options: {'A': 'blood tests for thyroid function', 'B': 'lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid examination', 'C': 'brain magnetic resonance imaging (', 'D': 'positron emission tomography (', 'E': 'electroencephalogram (', 'F': 'scan'}
answer: lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid examination

question: A 68-year-old woman with a history of type-II diabetes and mental illness, was admitted due to symptoms of anxiety and fear, reduced mobility, and urinary incontinence. Despite treatment for Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) with various medications, her symptoms relapsed. In addition to her mental symptoms, her physical examination revealed an unstable gait. Lab results indicated high levels of TSH along with thyroid lesions. Brain scans showed atrophy and leukoaraiosis. Despite treatment with venlafaxine and oxazepam, her cognitive function declined rapidly. Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid examination revealed high glucose and protein levels, along with a high anti-glutamate receptor (NMDA) ratio. After a diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis (AE), she was treated with immunoglobulin and methylprednisolone, leading to a gradual recovery in cognitive and emotional function.What is the most appropriate diagnosis for a 68-year-old woman with type-II diabetes, anxiety, fear, unstable gait, urinary incontinence, high TSH level, brain atrophy, leukoaraiosis, and high cerebrospinal fluid glucose, protein, and anti-glutamate receptor (NMDA) ratio?
options: {'A': 'multiple sclerosis', 'B': 'hypothyroidism', 'C': "parkinson's disease", 'D': 'normal pressure hydrocephalus', 'E': "alzheimer's disease", 'F': 'autoimmune encephalitis'}

clinical_note:
A 44-year-old female with a history of asthma, essential hypertension, class 3 obesity, depression, and poor social and economic background was intermittently followed during the previous four years for persistent cutaneous candidiasis with intertrigo in the inframammary, inguinal, and lower abdominal regions (Figure ).
She had been treated with topical antifungal, oral fluconazole and oral itraconazole with no improvement, which was believed to be because of poor hygiene and questionable therapeutic compliance. A worsening in the skin rash with exudate, pruritus, and a change to a violaceous colour, with scaly papules and vesicles (Figures , ) led to the performance of a skin biopsy which revealed (Figure ) orthokeratotic hyperkeratosis in the epidermis with areas of parakeratosis and, in the papillary dermis, there was an infiltrate of cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and reniform nuclei that showed positive CD1a and S100 proteins on the immunohistochemistry and negative CD163 (Figure ).
The patient denied constitutional, musculoskeletal, neurological, or urinary complaints. She underwent a complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), thoracic-abdominal-pelvic computed tomography (CT), and bone scintigraphy. Brain MRI depicted mild chronic microvascular changes in the white matter, unchanged from a prior study. CT demonstrated a thickening of the renal pelvis (4 mm) in the right kidney with a slight urothelial dilation (Figure ). The rest of the exams did not reveal further organ involvement.
After considering the skin histology, the extensive cutaneous involvement, and the infiltrative urothelial involvement, it was evident this was a multi-system process. A consultation with Hematology/Oncology, led to induction treatment with prednisolone and vinblastine-based chemotherapy. At six weeks of chemotherapy, there was a partial regression of the skin lesions (Figure ) and a resolution of the urothelium lesion in imaging exam (CT).
The disease was in continuous regression and considering the extension of affected skin tissue a second round of chemotherapy with prednisolone and vinblastine was administered for six weeks. There was a resolution of all the lesions following this second round, and the patient underwent maintenance therapy consisting of administrating mercaptopurine daily and prednisolone/vinblastine every three weeks during 12 months, staying in remission (Figure ).
Six months after the end of maintenance therapy the patient had a recurrence of the disease and started second-line chemotherapy with clofarabine and cytosine arabinoside (ARA-C). The patient did not comply with the treatment and the disease progressed. As a result of skin ulceration, she developed skin and soft tissue infection that evolved into septic shock and did not survive despite intensive care support.
topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: A 44-year-old female with a complex health history, including asthma, hypertension, obesity and depression, was presented with persistent skin candidiasis. Despite previous treatments with antifungal drugs, the patient's condition did not improve. A skin biopsy examination revealed abnormal cell formations, leading to a referral to Hematology/Oncology. The patient was then treated with prednisolone and vinblastine-based chemotherapy. This regimen initially resulted in a regression of her skin lesions, however, due to non-compliance with the treatment, the disease recurred.Which chemotherapeutic agent used in the patient's treatment regimen led to an initial improvement of the skin condition, but failed to maintain remission due to patient non-compliance?
options: {'A': 'fluconazole', 'B': 'prednisolone', 'C': 'mercaptopurine', 'D': 'vinblastine', 'E': 'itraconazole'}

question: A 44-year-old woman with a complex medical and socio-economic history has been managing persistent cutaneous candidiasis. Despite various treatments, her condition worsened, leading to a skin biopsy and a CT scan revealing thickening of the renal pelvis in the right kidney. Her non-compliance with treatment led to disease recurrence and a decline in her health status.Based on the patient's history, which factors could have influenced the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition?
options: {'A': "only the patient's pre-existing health conditions contributed to the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition.", 'B': 'the presence of a braf v600e mutation was the main factor in the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition.', 'C': "the progression and treatment outcomes of the patient's condition were not significantly affected by her socio-economic background or health conditions.", 'D': "the patient's socio-economic background had no influence on the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition.", 'E': "the patient's social and economic background, existing health conditions, and non-compliance with treatment regimens likely played significant roles in the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition.", 'F': "only the patient's socio-economic background influenced the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition."}
answer: the patient's social and economic background, existing health conditions, and non-compliance with treatment regimens likely played significant roles in the progression and treatment outcomes of her condition.

CT demonstrated a thickening of the renal pelvis (4 mm) in the right kidney with a slight urothelial dilation (Figure ). The rest of the exams did not reveal further organ involvement.
After considering the skin histology, the extensive cutaneous involvement, and the infiltrative urothelial involvement, it was evident this was a multi-system process. A consultation with Hematology/Oncology, led to induction treatment with prednisolone and vinblastine-based chemotherapy. At six weeks of chemotherapy, there was a partial regression of the skin lesions (Figure ) and a resolution of the urothelium lesion in imaging exam (CT).
The disease was in continuous regression and considering the extension of affected skin tissue a second round of chemotherapy with prednisolone and vinblastine was administered for six weeks. There was a resolution of all the lesions following this second round, and the patient underwent maintenance therapy consisting of administrating mercaptopurine daily and prednisolone/vinblastine every three weeks during 12 months, staying in remission (Figure ).
Six months after the end of maintenance therapy the patient had a recurrence of the disease and started second-line chemotherapy with clofarabine and cytosine arabinoside (ARA-C). The patient did not comply with the treatment and the disease progressed. As a result of skin ulceration, she developed skin and soft tissue infection that evolved into septic shock and did not survive despite intensive care support.
keypoint: the most likely cell origin (langerhans cells)
topic: interprets laboratory or other study findings
question: A 44-year-old female with a history of persistent skin rash was evaluated. The rash, characterized by pruritus, exudate, and a violaceous hue with the presence of scaly papules and vesicles, had not responded to antifungal treatments. A skin biopsy revealed an unusual finding in the papillary dermis, with an infiltrate of cells exhibiting eosinophilic cytoplasm and reniform nuclei. The immunohistochemistry of these cells was positive for CD1a and S100 proteins but negative for CD163. The patient underwent further diagnostic evaluations, including a brain MRI and CT scan, which revealed only a thickening of the renal pelvis in the right kidney.Considering the immunohistochemistry results from the skin biopsy, what is the most likely type of cells involved in this patient's skin condition?
options: {'A': 'merkel cells', 'B': 'sebaceous gland cells', 'C': 'langerhans cells', 'D': 'dermal fibroblasts', 'E': 'melanocytes', 'F': 'keratinocytes'}

question: The patient, a 44-year-old woman with a history of persistent cutaneous candidiasis, had undergone several treatments without success. Despite using topical antifungal, oral fluconazole, and oral itraconazole, her condition worsened, leading to further diagnostic tests. A skin biopsy was performed, and the results, along with imaging studies, suggested a multi-system process. Accordingly, the treatment approach had to be reconsidered.What was the subsequent pharmacotherapy regimen administered to the patient after the biopsy and imaging results?
options: {'A': 'clofarabine and cytosine arabinoside (ara-', 'B': 'azithromycin and clarithromycin therapy', 'C': 'amoxicillin and clavulanate therapy', 'D': 'fluconazole and itraconazole therapy', 'E': 'prednisolone and vinblastine-based chemotherapy', 'F': 'therapy'}

clinical_note:
A 41-year-old Japanese woman presented to our clinic with a 4 month history of bilateral groin pain and right buttock pain. Her right hip was more painful than her left hip. There was no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. Her medical history included iron-deficiency anemia diagnosed 2 years earlier, after which she had been on iron supplements. She had no fracture episodes, including fragility fractures.
Her height, body weight, and body mass index were 155 cm, 42 kg, and 18.7 kg/m2, respectively. She was able to walk for approximately 10 minutes without a stick, albeit at a slow speed. Limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint were observed thus: flexion, 100°, internal rotation 5°, external rotation 15°, and abduction 20°, on both sides. She was able to perform a straight-leg raise of the right limb with substantial pain. The neurovascular status of both lower extremities was intact. The Japanese Orthopaedic Association scoring system for the evaluation of hip-joint function (JOA hip score) was 46 points for her right hip and 56 points for her left hip. The score was based on a total of 100 points, comprising 40 for pain, 20 for range of motion, 20 for the ability to walk, and 20 for activities of daily living [].
Standard radiographs of both hips (Fig. a–c) demonstrated no characteristic findings such as the crescent sign, sclerotic band pattern, and collapse of the femoral head, and no joint space narrowing was seen in either femoral head. MRI of both hips (Fig. d, e) presented a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head in the T1 weighted image and high signal region in almost all of the femoral head in the short tau inversion recovery (STIR). The oblique axial views of the proton density-weighted image showed a low-signal sinuous line in the anteromedial region of the femoral head (Fig. ). Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) values were low in both femoral necks. Bone mineral density was 0.909 g/cm2 (T-score –0.9, Z-score −0.8) in the lumbar spine, 0.594 g/cm2 (T-score −1.8, Z-score −1.4) in the right femoral neck, and 0.529 g/cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.0) in the left femoral neck. Laboratory findings were as follows: C-reactive protein (CRP) 0.03 mg/dl (normal range: 0–0.5 mg/dl); alkaline phosphatase 608 IU/l (40–150 IU/l); calcium 9.0 mg/dl (8.4–10.2 mg/dl); albumin 4.4 g/d (3.9–4.9 g/d); and hemoglobin 9.7 g/dl (12–16 g/dl). Bone turnover markers were as follows: tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b (TRACP-5b) 463 mU/dl (premenopausal normal range: 120–420 mU/dl) and total procollagen type 1 N-terminal propeptide (Total P1NP) 72.7 ng/ml (26.4–98.2 ng/ml). We diagnosed bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and classified it as stage 1 in both femoral heads, according to the Association Research Circulation Osseous (ARCO) classification [].
The patient was instructed not to take as much weight as possible using sticks on the right side. Her symptoms improved immediately. However, 6 months later, her symptoms increased slightly without any traumatic episodes. Radiographic findings indicated almost no change (Fig. a–c). However, a slight signal change in the medial subcapital region was observed in the MRI scan (Fig. d, e). Her pain gradually increased thereafter, and 10 months after her first visit, walking became difficult. The JOA hip score decreased to 34 points in both hips; still, no changes could be observed in the radiograph (Fig. a–c). MRI of both hips showed a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks, with bone marrow edema around the fracture (Fig. d, e). Because the cause of the fractures was not identified, the DEXA and bone turnover markers were measured again, and 25-hydroxy (OH) vitamin D was measured for the first time. All DEXA values decreased. The bone mineral density was 0.849 g/cm2 (T-score −1.5, Z-score −1.2) in the lumbar spine, 0.527 g/ cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.1) in the right femoral neck, and 0.490 g/cm2 (T-score −2.7, Z-score −2.4) in the left femoral neck. TRACP-5b level increased to 607 mU/dl, and total P1NP decreased to 52.7 ng/ml. Her 25(OH) vitamin D level was 11.1 ng/dL and she was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency. Based on the above results, our diagnosis was bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The patient underwent internal fixation of both hips with sliding hip screws (Dual SC screw system; Kisco, Kobe, Japan) to stabilize the stress fractures. In addition, the reaming performed before inserting of the sliding hip screw served as core decompression for the femoral heads [, ]. The specimens obtained from the reaming were examined histologically. Definitive findings of osteonecrosis such as bone marrow necrosis and loss of osteocyte nuclei in the femoral heads were observed (Fig. ). Postoperative radiographs showed no evidence of displacement of the fractures (Fig. ). We administered eldecalcitol 0.75 μg per day orally for vitamin D deficiency, and daily subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate. In the immediate postoperative period, the patient began to bear weight as tolerated with the use of an assistive device bilaterally. One month postoperatively, she was able to walk without pain and used a cane part time. She eventually regained full walking ability without a cane 3 months after surgery. Furthermore, her JOA hip score improved to 90 points in both hip joints at 5 months after surgery. Radiographs showed no evidence of recurrent stress fracture in the femoral neck or progression of osteonecrosis (Fig. ). Sequential oblique axial MRI showed that the necrotic region of the femoral head had decreased 5 months after surgery (Fig. ).
keypoint: bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head

question: A 41-year-old woman has been experiencing bilateral groin pain, more severe on the right, for the past few months. She has a past history of iron-deficiency anemia but denies any history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. Physical examination reveals limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint. Imaging studies, including MRI, reveal low bone mineral density in both femoral necks and specific signal changes in the femoral heads. Ten months after the onset of her symptoms, she notes difficulty in walking, and a subsequent MRI reveals nondisplaced fractures on the medial side of both femoral necks.Based on the patient's symptoms and imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
options: {'A': 'osteoarthritis of the hip', 'B': 'bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head', 'C': 'slipped capital femoral epiphysis', 'D': 'pelvic fracture', 'E': 'hip labral tear', 'F': 'femoroacetabular impingement'}
answer: bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head

question: A 41-year-old woman presented with bilateral groin and right buttock pain, with her right hip being more painful. She had a history of iron-deficiency anemia and no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. On examination, she had limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint and substantial pain when raising her right limb. Further investigations, including MRI and Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA), were conducted. Laboratory findings were mostly within normal limits with an exception of elevated alkaline phosphatase and low hemoglobin. She was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Over the next 10 months, her pain increased, and walking became difficult. MRI of both hips showed a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks, with bone marrow edema around the fracture. She was found to have a vitamin D deficiency. options: {'A': 'osteoporosis', 'B': 'trauma', 'C': 'osteonecrosis of the femoral head', 'D': 'osteoarthritis', 'E': 'vitamin d deficiency'}

MRI of both hips (Fig. d, e) presented a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head in the T1 weighted image and high signal region in almost all of the femoral head in the short tau inversion recovery (STIR). The oblique axial views of the proton density-weighted image showed a low-signal sinuous line in the anteromedial region of the femoral head (Fig. ). Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) values were low in both femoral necks. Bone mineral density was 0.909 g/cm2 (T-score –0.9, Z-score −0.8) in the lumbar spine, 0.594 g/cm2 (T-score −1.8, Z-score −1.4) in the right femoral neck, and 0.529 g/cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.0) in the left femoral neck. Laboratory findings were as follows: C-reactive protein (CRP) 0.03 mg/dl (normal range: 0–0.5 mg/dl); alkaline phosphatase 608 IU/l (40–150 IU/l); calcium 9.0 mg/dl (8.4–10.2 mg/dl); albumin 4.4 g/d (3.9–4.9 g/d); and hemoglobin 9.7 g/dl (12–16 g/dl). Bone turnover markers were as follows: tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b (TRACP-5b) 463 mU/dl (premenopausal normal range: 120–420 mU/dl) and total procollagen type 1 N-terminal propeptide (Total P1NP) 72.7 ng/ml (26.4–98.2 ng/ml). We diagnosed bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and classified it as stage 1 in both femoral heads, according to the Association Research Circulation Osseous (ARCO) classification [].
The patient was instructed not to take as much weight as possible using sticks on the right side. Her symptoms improved immediately. However, 6 months later, her symptoms increased slightly without any traumatic episodes. Radiographic findings indicated almost no change (Fig. a–c). However, a slight signal change in the medial subcapital region was observed in the MRI scan (Fig. d, e). Her pain gradually increased thereafter, and 10 months after her first visit, walking became difficult. The JOA hip score decreased to 34 points in both hips; still, no changes could be observed in the radiograph (Fig. a–c). MRI of both hips showed a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks, with bone marrow edema around the fracture (Fig. d, e). Because the cause of the fractures was not identified, the DEXA and bone turnover markers were measured again, and 25-hydroxy (OH) vitamin D was measured for the first time. All DEXA values decreased. The bone mineral density was 0.849 g/cm2 (T-score −1.5, Z-score −1.2) in the lumbar spine, 0.527 g/ cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.1) in the right femoral neck, and 0.490 g/cm2 (T-score −2.7, Z-score −2.4) in the left femoral neck. TRACP-5b level increased to 607 mU/dl, and total P1NP decreased to 52.7 ng/ml. Her 25(OH) vitamin D level was 11.1 ng/dL and she was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency. Based on the above results, our diagnosis was bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The patient underwent internal fixation of both hips with sliding hip screws (Dual SC screw system; Kisco, Kobe, Japan) to stabilize the stress fractures. In addition, the reaming performed before inserting of the sliding hip screw served as core decompression for the femoral heads [, ]. The specimens obtained from the reaming were examined histologically. Definitive findings of osteonecrosis such as bone marrow necrosis and loss of osteocyte nuclei in the femoral heads were observed (Fig. ). Postoperative radiographs showed no evidence of displacement of the fractures (Fig. ). We administered eldecalcitol 0.75 μg per day orally for vitamin D deficiency, and daily subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate. In the immediate postoperative period, the patient began to bear weight as tolerated with the use of an assistive device bilaterally. One month postoperatively, she was able to walk without pain and used a cane part time. She eventually regained full walking ability without a cane 3 months after surgery. Furthermore, her JOA hip score improved to 90 points in both hip joints at 5 months after surgery. Radiographs showed no evidence of recurrent stress fracture in the femoral neck or progression of osteonecrosis (Fig. ). Sequential oblique axial MRI showed that the necrotic region of the femoral head had decreased 5 months after surgery (Fig. ).
keypoint: such as vitamin D and calcium supplement, proper exercise to build up muscles

question: A 41-year-old woman presented with a four-month history of bilateral groin and right buttock pain, with the right side being more painful. Her medical history included iron-deficiency anemia. An MRI scan revealed a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head. She was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Her symptoms slightly increased six months later, despite the use of walking sticks. An MRI scan taken 10 months after her first visit revealed a non-displaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks, with bone marrow edema around the fracture. Further tests showed decreased bone mineral density, and she was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency. She underwent surgery to stabilize the fractures and was prescribed vitamin D and teriparatide acetate.What preventive measures might have improved this patient's condition and potentially averted the need for surgery?
options: {'A': 'increasing iron supplements', 'B': 'regular intake of vitamin d and calcium supplements along with muscle-strengthening exercises', 'C': 'weight gain for increased bone density', 'D': 'regular use of walking sticks', 'E': 'prolonged bed rest'}
answer: regular intake of vitamin d and calcium supplements along with muscle-strengthening exercises

question: A 41-year-old Japanese woman with a history of iron-deficiency anemia presented with bilateral groin and right buttock pain for 4 months. Her right hip was more painful than her left. There was no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. She had limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint. Standard radiographs of both hips showed no characteristic findings, however, MRI presented a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) values were low in both femoral necks. The patient was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and classified as stage 1 in both femoral heads. Despite initial improvement with conservative management, her symptoms worsened over time. Further radiographs and MRI scans showed a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks with bone marrow edema around the fracture. She was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency and bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. She underwent surgical intervention and was administered eldecalcitol for vitamin D deficiency and daily subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate. Postoperatively, she regained her full walking ability and showed improvement in her hip joint scores. Sequential oblique axial MRI showed that the necrotic region of the femoral head had decreased 5 months after surgery.What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for a patient diagnosed with osteonecrosis of the femoral head and vitamin D deficiency?
options: {'A': 'Alendronate', 'B': 'Risedronate', 'C': 'No pharmacotherapy at this time', 'D': 'Calcitonin', 'E': 'Eldecalcitol and Teriparatide acetate', 'F': 'Calcium and Vitamin D supplements only'}

question: A 41-year-old woman with a history of iron-deficiency anemia presented with bilateral groin pain and right buttock pain. She had no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. She had limited passive motion in both hip joints and substantial pain during a straight-leg raise of the right limb. Investigations including radiographs, MRI scans, and laboratory findings led to a diagnosis of bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Her symptoms increased over a period of six months, with a subsequent MRI revealing a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks. She was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency and bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. She underwent internal fixation of both hips to stabilize the fractures, was treated with eldecalcitol for vitamin D deficiency, and was given daily subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate.What is a significant adverse effect commonly associated with the use of bisphosphonates, a medication class often prescribed for conditions such as osteoporosis?
options: {'A': 'pulmonary embolism', 'B': 'osteonecrosis of the jaw', 'C': 'cardiac arrhythmia', 'D': 'liver damage', 'E': 'stroke'}

question: A 41-year-old woman came to the clinic with persistent bilateral groin and right buttock pain. Her medical history included iron-deficiency anemia. Initial investigations showed no signs of trauma or alcohol abuse. The patient's mobility was compromised and further examinations including MRI led to the diagnosis of osteonecrosis of the femoral head. After an initial period of improvement, her pain increased and mobility issues worsened. Further investigations revealed nondisplaced subcapital fractures in both femoral necks and vitamin D deficiency. A comprehensive treatment plan was then implemented to address these issues.What was the combined treatment strategy that was used to manage this patient's conditions?
options: {'A': 'nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and iron supplementation', 'B': 'analgesic medication and weight loss program', 'C': 'bisphosphonate therapy and physical therapy', 'D': 'internal fixation of the hips and vitamin d supplementation', 'E': 'corticosteroid treatment and calcium supplementation', 'F': 'joint replacement surgery and iron supplementation', 'G': 'steroid therapy and vitamin c supplementation', 'H': 'physiotherapy and calcium supplementation'}
answer: internal fixation of the hips and vitamin d supplementation

clinical_note:
A 35-year-old male patient presented with a six-month history of pain in the anterior chest and neck. His pain initially had been mild but had become severe in the last three weeks. He was afebrile and did not have any constitutional symptoms. On examination, marked tenderness of the right sternoclavicular joint was noted. Initial laboratory investigations, tuberculosis workup, and chest X-rays were unremarkable. However, further study with MRI revealed subchondral bone marrow edema and enhancement involving the medial end of the right clavicle. In addition, mild effusion of the right sternoclavicular joint and surrounding soft-tissue edema was also seen (Figure , ).
Given the patient's radiological and clinical findings, suspicion of SAPHO syndrome was raised. He was given an initial trial of paracetamol and NSAIDs and he showed remarkable improvement on his monthly follow-up visits. Though a biopsy was offered, the patient refused to undergo one and has shown no relapse to date thanks to the dramatic response to NSAIDs.
topic: knows signs/symptoms of selected disorders
question: A 35-year-old male patient has been experiencing pain in his chest and neck for six months. This pain has been intensifying over the past three weeks. He does not have any fever or other systemic symptoms. During the physical exam, we noticed significant tenderness in his right sternoclavicular joint. While initial lab tests and chest X-rays didn't reveal anything unusual, an MRI showed signs of subchondral bone marrow edema in the medial end of the right clavicle, a mild effusion in the right sternoclavicular joint, and some soft-tissue edema surrounding the joint. These clinical and radiological findings are suggestive of a particular condition. The patient was treated with paracetamol and NSAIDs, which led to a significant improvement in his symptoms.Based on the described signs and symptoms, which syndrome is most likely to be suspected in this patient?
options: {'A': 'ehlers-danlos syndrome', 'B': 'marfan syndrome', 'C': "reiter's syndrome", 'D': 'sapho syndrome', 'E': 'guillain-barre syndrome'}

question: A 35-year-old male patient has been experiencing pain in the anterior chest and neck for the past six months. The pain, initially mild, has significantly worsened over the last three weeks. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness of the right sternoclavicular joint, but he does not have any constitutional symptoms and is afebrile. Initial laboratory investigations, including a tuberculosis workup, and chest X-rays did not yield any significant findings. An MRI, however, showed subchondral bone marrow edema and enhancement at the medial end of the right clavicle, mild effusion of the right sternoclavicular joint, and surrounding soft-tissue edema. Based on these clinical and radiological findings, the patient was suspected to have SAPHO syndrome. An initial trial of paracetamol and NSAIDs led to a remarkable improvement in his condition during monthly follow-up visits. Despite the offer of a biopsy, the patient declined but has shown no relapse to date, likely due to the effective response to NSAIDs.What additional physical finding is most likely in a patient suspected to have SAPHO syndrome based on clinical and radiological findings?
options: {'A': 'Pitting edema', 'B': 'Skin lesions', 'C': 'Swollen lymph nodes', 'D': 'Jaundice', 'E': 'Hematoma', 'F': 'Clubbing of fingers'}

However, further study with MRI revealed subchondral bone marrow edema and enhancement involving the medial end of the right clavicle. In addition, mild effusion of the right sternoclavicular joint and surrounding soft-tissue edema was also seen (Figure , ).
Given the patient's radiological and clinical findings, suspicion of SAPHO syndrome was raised. He was given an initial trial of paracetamol and NSAIDs and he showed remarkable improvement on his monthly follow-up visits. Though a biopsy was offered, the patient refused to undergo one and has shown no relapse to date thanks to the dramatic response to NSAIDs.

question: A 35-year-old male presents with a six-month history of pain in the anterior chest and neck, which has recently intensified. He is afebrile and does not exhibit any constitutional symptoms. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness of the right sternoclavicular joint. Routine laboratory investigations, tuberculosis tests, and chest X-rays are unremarkable. However, MRI imaging reveals subchondral bone marrow edema and enhancement at the medial end of the right clavicle, as well as mild effusion of the right sternoclavicular joint and surrounding soft-tissue edema. Based on these radiological and clinical findings, the patient is suspected to have Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis (SAPHO) syndrome, a condition associated with chronic recurrent osteitis. The patient responds well to paracetamol and NSAIDs and shows significant improvement during monthly follow-up visits. Despite the suggestion of a biopsy, the patient declines and continues to show no signs of relapse due to the positive response to NSAIDs.What condition is associated with chronic recurrent osteitis, as seen in a 35-year-old male with pain in the anterior chest and neck, marked tenderness of the right sternoclavicular joint, and radiological findings of subchondral bone marrow edema and enhancement at the medial end of the right clavicle?
options: {'A': 'Ankylosing Spondylitis', 'B': 'Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis (SAPHO) syndrome', 'C': 'Gout', 'D': 'Osteoarthritis', 'E': 'Bone tuberculosis', 'F': 'Rheumatoid Arthritis', 'G': 'Polymyalgia Rheumatica', 'H': "Sjogren's syndrome", 'I': 'Psoriatic Arthritis'}
answer: Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis (SAPHO) syndrome

clinical_note:
A 66-year-old male with back pain and cough for two weeks was admitted to the First Hospital of Jiaxing on 8 August 2019. A thoracic computed tomography (CT) scan revealed that the malignant tumor on the left upper lobe was complicated by distal obstructive inflammation, the enlargement of the left hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes, and the multiple bone metastases on 25 August 2019 (Fig. A). Immunohistochemical (IHC) results of the posterior iliac bone marrow biopsy specimen showed the positive expression of CD3, CD20, CD34, CD235a, and NPO, and the negative CD61 expression. IHC results of an endoscopic biopsy specimen of the bronchial mucosa on the upper left lobe showed the positive expression of TTF1, CK7, NapsinA, Ki67, CK, and EMA, and the negative expression of CK5/6, P40, CgA, Syn, and CD45 on 6 September 2019. Histopathologic observations showed infiltration of atypia cells in mucosal and fibrous tissues. The detection tools of pathology and cytology included automatic IHC staining (BenchMark XT, Roche, The United States), digital slice scanner, image analysis software (Pannoramic 250, 3DHistech, Hungary), and microscope (Eclipse Ci-S, Nikon, Japan). Finally, the patient was diagnosed with stage IVb lung adenocarcinoma combing with bone metastases.
To seek potential therapeutic opportunities, the FFPE tissue and control sample (white blood cell) of the patient were detected using a 733-gene NGS panel in a College of American Pathologists (CAP) and Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) certificated lab. Sequencing reads were mapped against the hg19/GRCh37 genome, and duplicate reads were removed, followed by variants calling in targeted regions using an in-house developed bioinformatics algorithm. The algorithm utilized a filtering model containing background error correction, strand bias, base quality, mapping quality, short tandem repeat regions, and low-quality mapping ratio 25 []. The NGS analysis results indicated that the patient had an EGFR exon 19 p.L747_S752del somatic mutation with an allelic fraction of 73.19% and TP53 p.H179L germline mutation. Besides, the whole chromosome 7 and 5q deletion were detected using NGS-based copy number variation (CNV) analyses (Fig. ), which were classical abnormalities associated with MDS. According to the clinical inquiry, the patient was a farmer by occupation, which means that he has long been exposed to certain chemicals such as pesticides, fertilizers, and solvents containing benzene. In addition, he smoked for 40 years. Taking all these findings together, we suspected the patient with secondary MDS. The results of the physiological blood indexes and the bone marrow aspiration test showed a decrease of platelet counts and the elevation of myelocyte counts. The proportion of blast was 5%, and the morphology of the cells presented the characteristics of MDS, which further confirmed our speculation (Fig. and Additional file : Fig. S1).
In terms of treatment, the EGFR-positive mutation patient was administered with gefitinib starting from 20 August 2019. Due to decreasing platelet counts, azacitidine was administrated for four courses of treatment. However, the thrombocytopenia had not been significantly improved, and the size of the maximal tumor in the lung lesion did not decrease after seven months’ treatment (Fig. B). On 10 April 2020, a pathological report showed the infiltration of poorly differentiated cancer cells into the fibrous tissue. IHC results suggested the neuroendocrine tumor, in which small cell carcinoma and atypical carcinoid tumor accounted for about 40% and 60%, respectively. On 7 April and 28 April 2020, considering positive PD-L1 expression and high tumor mutation burden (TMB) in the tissue sample, the patient was administrated with toripalimab (a PD-1 inhibitor) and bevacizumab. Platelet counts returned to near-normal levels gradually, and the tumor lesion shrank obviously (Fig. ). It was concluded that the patient reached a partial response (PR) (Fig. C). The progression-free survival was four months.
keypoint: EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (such as osimertinib, gefitinib)

Initial treatment with gefitinib, an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, did not significantly improve his condition. Subsequently, he was treated with toripalimab, a PD-1 inhibitor, and bevacizumab due to positive PD-L1 expression and a high tumor mutation burden.Which treatment regimen led to a noticeable improvement in this patient's condition?
options: {'A': 'administration of gefitinib alone', 'B': 'administration of bevacizumab alone', 'C': 'administration of gefitinib in combination with toripalimab.', 'D': 'administration of toripalimab alone', 'E': 'combination of toripalimab and bevacizumab'}

question: A 66-year-old male with a history of smoking and chemical exposure was admitted to the hospital. He had symptoms of back pain and cough. Imaging revealed a tumor in his left lung and multiple bone metastases. Genetic testing identified an EGFR exon 19 p.L747_S752del somatic mutation and TP53 p.H179L germline mutation. He was diagnosed with stage IVb lung adenocarcinoma with bone metastases. Despite treatment, the patient's condition showed minimal improvement.Given the patient's diagnosis and genetic mutations, what is the expected prognosis?
options: {'A': 'the disease in such patients usually progresses slowly and can be managed with medication.', 'B': 'these patients often experience a moderate decline in health with periods of stability.', 'C': 'patients with this condition typically remain stable, with no disease progression.', 'D': 'the prognosis for a patient with stage ivb lung adenocarcinoma with an egfr exon 19 p.l747_s752del somatic mutation and tp53 p.h179l germline mutation is generally poor, with rapid disease progression despite treatment.', 'E': 'the prognosis for such a patient is generally good, with a high chance of complete recovery.'}
answer: the prognosis for a patient with stage ivb lung adenocarcinoma with an egfr exon 19 p.l747_s752del somatic mutation and tp53 p.h179l germline mutation is generally poor, with rapid disease progression despite treatment.
