clinical_note:
A 14-year-old male adolescent presented to the emergency department with subfebrile temperatures for 1 week and localized pain in his right popliteal fossa for 3 days. Prior to the onset of these symptoms, he had been immobilized for several days following a minor sports injury.
The adolescent had no permanent medication and no prior medical history except for an asymptomatic ATD diagnosed at the age of six by functional antithrombin assay (antithrombin activity of 57%, age adapted reference: 77–125%). Since at that time, there were no clinical signs of thrombosis, the diagnosis of ATD did not lead to any therapeutic consequences. Screening for ATD at this early age had been carried out on parental request, as his mother was diagnosed with ATD in her early adulthood. Interestingly, his mother now reported that she had very recently been diagnosed with IVCA (preexisting chromogenic test results showed an antithrombin activity of 50% for the mother, the age adjusted reference range being 80 to 130%).
The coexistence of other hereditary thrombophilic disorders in our patient and his mother (protein S deficiency, protein C deficiency, factor V Leiden mutation, prothrombin-mutation, antiphospholipid syndrome) was ruled out by respective laboratory analyses.
Laboratory blood analysis in the emergency department showed markedly elevated D-dimers of 25 mg/l FEU (reference: < 0.5 mg/l FEU) and of C-reactive protein (CrP) of 184 mg/l (reference < 5 mg/l). Antithrombin activity on admission was reduced to 61% (age adjusted reference 83–118%).
A vascular ultrasound examination upon admission confirmed the clinically suspected thrombosis of the right lower extremity involving the external iliac, common and superficial femoral as well as the popliteal vein. The ultrasound examination of the left lower extremity veins did not give evidence of thromboses upon admission. The patient was treated with continuous infusion of unfractionated heparin at a therapeutical dose including several bolus administrations and antithrombin (4000 IE within the first 36 h) was substituted reaching levels in the target range between 80 and 100%. Subsequent monitoring of the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) showed an insufficient response to heparin treatment (aPTT was 29 s before the administration of heparin and did not exceed a maximum value of 33.6 s during heparin treatment). The anticoagulative therapy was therefore switched to direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban at a dose of 1.5–2.0 μg/kg/min, which led to target aPTT values of 50–60s.
Due to the elevated CrP levels and subfebrile temperatures, empirical antibiotic treatment with intravenous cefuroxim was initiated.
A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan on day three confirmed a complete DVT of the right lower extremity, and now additionally extended thromboses of the left lower extremity and thrombosis of both iliac vessels. Furthermore, it revealed an occlusion of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with prominent venous lumbar collaterals, suggestive of IVCA. Surrounding the lumbar vertebrae, several of these collaterals appeared to be fully thrombotic, which was confirmed by angiography (Fig. A).
The following day, a catheter-directed local thrombolysis using recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) at a daily dose of 0.25 mg/kg was initiated in both extremities and carried out for a total of 48 h. For the right leg, an additional ultrasound-accelerated thrombolysis using the EKOS® system was performed.
During hospitalization, the anticoagulative therapy was switched from argatroban to the vitamin K antagonist phenprocoumon with a target International Normalized Ratio (INR) of 2.0–2.5. Oral anticoagulation will most likely be continued lifelong due to the combination of extended multilocal thromboses with underlying ATD, as well as IVCA, which in itself is a risk factor for thrombosis.
The patient was discharged on day eight after hospital admission. An ultrasound examination upon discharge showed full recanalization of the femoral and iliac veins of both legs.
During a routine follow-up 1 week later, the patient presented free of any clinical complaints. However, despite continued oral anticoagulation since hospital discharge, vascular ultrasound now revealed extended re-thrombosis of both the right and left pelvic axis and the right lower extremity, thus leading to a second hospital admission and re-induction of therapy with both intravenous antithrombin and catheter-directed thrombolysis.
Recanalization of the right lower extremity and pelvic axis was subsequently achieved, whereby IVC occlusion was confirmed (Fig. B). However, the left pelvic vessels remained thrombotic even after 5 days of catheter-directed thrombolysis.
Surprisingly, one of the angiographies allowed for location of the occluded area of the IVC by rendezvous-technique between the superior and inferior vena cava, which prior to this had been thought to be atretic (Fig. C). The vessel was successfully recanalized using balloon dilation and subsequent stenting (Fig. D).
Throughout the clinical stay, the patient’s oral anticoagulation with phenprocoumon was intensified to a new target INR of 2.5–3.0 in order to prevent re-thrombosis.
The patient was discharged from hospital on day seven after admission. Regular follow-up examinations at our outpatient clinic did not give evidence for any new thrombotic events to date (time since first occurrence of thrombosis was 9 months).
Concerning the thrombotic left iliac vessels, a follow-up angiographic intervention relying on special equipment was performed, but recanalization could not be achieved.
Fortunately, the IVC of the patient’s mother could also be recanalized by angiographic intervention.
topic: underlying processes/pathways
question: A 14-year-old male with an asymptomatic antithrombin deficiency (ATD) diagnosis from childhood presented to the emergency department due to subfebrile temperatures and localized pain in his right popliteal fossa. He had recently been immobilized due to a minor sports injury. His mother also had ATD and a diagnosis of Inferior Vena Cava Atresia (IVCA). Lab analysis revealed elevated D-dimers and C-reactive protein levels and reduced antithrombin activity. Vascular ultrasound confirmed thrombosis in the right lower extremity. Despite initial treatment with heparin and antithrombin, the patient showed an insufficient response, leading to a switch in treatment to argatroban. An MRI scan confirmed extended thromboses of both lower extremities and the inferior vena cava, suggesting IVCA. The patient underwent catheter-directed local thrombolysis and was later switched to the vitamin K antagonist phenprocoumon for anticoagulation therapy. Despite initial recanalization of the femoral and iliac veins, the patient experienced re-thrombosis, leading to further hospitalization and treatment. The patient's oral anticoagulation therapy was intensified to prevent further re-thrombosis. The patient's mother's IVC was also successfully recanalized.What is the role of the coagulation pathway in the development of thrombosis in patients with antithrombin deficiency?
options: {'A': 'Antithrombin deficiency results in decreased platelet activity, leading to a reduced risk of thrombosis.', 'B': 'Antithrombin deficiency causes a decrease in the level of procoagulant factors, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis.', 'C': 'Antithrombin deficiency leads to excessive bleeding due to impaired clot formation.', 'D': 'Antithrombin deficiency leads to the overproduction of platelets, which does not contribute to thrombosis.', 'E': 'Antithrombin deficiency leads to a hypercoagulable state due to impaired inhibition of thrombin and other coagulation factors, resulting in an increased risk of thrombosis.', 'F': 'Antithrombin deficiency prevents the breakdown of fibrin, leading to the formation of clots.'}
answer: Antithrombin deficiency leads to a hypercoagulable state due to impaired inhibition of thrombin and other coagulation factors, resulting in an increased risk of thrombosis.

clinical_note:
A 14-year-old male adolescent presented to the emergency department with subfebrile temperatures for 1 week and localized pain in his right popliteal fossa for 3 days. Prior to the onset of these symptoms, he had been immobilized for several days following a minor sports injury.
The adolescent had no permanent medication and no prior medical history except for an asymptomatic ATD diagnosed at the age of six by functional antithrombin assay (antithrombin activity of 57%, age adapted reference: 77–125%). Since at that time, there were no clinical signs of thrombosis, the diagnosis of ATD did not lead to any therapeutic consequences. Screening for ATD at this early age had been carried out on parental request, as his mother was diagnosed with ATD in her early adulthood. Interestingly, his mother now reported that she had very recently been diagnosed with IVCA (preexisting chromogenic test results showed an antithrombin activity of 50% for the mother, the age adjusted reference range being 80 to 130%).
The coexistence of other hereditary thrombophilic disorders in our patient and his mother (protein S deficiency, protein C deficiency, factor V Leiden mutation, prothrombin-mutation, antiphospholipid syndrome) was ruled out by respective laboratory analyses.
Laboratory blood analysis in the emergency department showed markedly elevated D-dimers of 25 mg/l FEU (reference: < 0.5 mg/l FEU) and of C-reactive protein (CrP) of 184 mg/l (reference < 5 mg/l). Antithrombin activity on admission was reduced to 61% (age adjusted reference 83–118%).
A vascular ultrasound examination upon admission confirmed the clinically suspected thrombosis of the right lower extremity involving the external iliac, common and superficial femoral as well as the popliteal vein. The ultrasound examination of the left lower extremity veins did not give evidence of thromboses upon admission. The patient was treated with continuous infusion of unfractionated heparin at a therapeutical dose including several bolus administrations and antithrombin (4000 IE within the first 36 h) was substituted reaching levels in the target range between 80 and 100%. Subsequent monitoring of the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) showed an insufficient response to heparin treatment (aPTT was 29 s before the administration of heparin and did not exceed a maximum value of 33.6 s during heparin treatment). The anticoagulative therapy was therefore switched to direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban at a dose of 1.5–2.0 μg/kg/min, which led to target aPTT values of 50–60s.
Due to the elevated CrP levels and subfebrile temperatures, empirical antibiotic treatment with intravenous cefuroxim was initiated.
A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan on day three confirmed a complete DVT of the right lower extremity, and now additionally extended thromboses of the left lower extremity and thrombosis of both iliac vessels. Furthermore, it revealed an occlusion of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with prominent venous lumbar collaterals, suggestive of IVCA. Surrounding the lumbar vertebrae, several of these collaterals appeared to be fully thrombotic, which was confirmed by angiography (Fig. A).
The following day, a catheter-directed local thrombolysis using recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) at a daily dose of 0.25 mg/kg was initiated in both extremities and carried out for a total of 48 h. For the right leg, an additional ultrasound-accelerated thrombolysis using the EKOS® system was performed.
During hospitalization, the anticoagulative therapy was switched from argatroban to the vitamin K antagonist phenprocoumon with a target International Normalized Ratio (INR) of 2.0–2.5. Oral anticoagulation will most likely be continued lifelong due to the combination of extended multilocal thromboses with underlying ATD, as well as IVCA, which in itself is a risk factor for thrombosis.
The patient was discharged on day eight after hospital admission. An ultrasound examination upon discharge showed full recanalization of the femoral and iliac veins of both legs.
During a routine follow-up 1 week later, the patient presented free of any clinical complaints. However, despite continued oral anticoagulation since hospital discharge, vascular ultrasound now revealed extended re-thrombosis of both the right and left pelvic axis and the right lower extremity, thus leading to a second hospital admission and re-induction of therapy with both intravenous antithrombin and catheter-directed thrombolysis.
Recanalization of the right lower extremity and pelvic axis was subsequently achieved, whereby IVC occlusion was confirmed (Fig. B). However, the left pelvic vessels remained thrombotic even after 5 days of catheter-directed thrombolysis.
Surprisingly, one of the angiographies allowed for location of the occluded area of the IVC by rendezvous-technique between the superior and inferior vena cava, which prior to this had been thought to be atretic (Fig. C). The vessel was successfully recanalized using balloon dilation and subsequent stenting (Fig. D).
Throughout the clinical stay, the patient’s oral anticoagulation with phenprocoumon was intensified to a new target INR of 2.5–3.0 in order to prevent re-thrombosis.
The patient was discharged from hospital on day seven after admission. Regular follow-up examinations at our outpatient clinic did not give evidence for any new thrombotic events to date (time since first occurrence of thrombosis was 9 months).
Concerning the thrombotic left iliac vessels, a follow-up angiographic intervention relying on special equipment was performed, but recanalization could not be achieved.
Fortunately, the IVC of the patient’s mother could also be recanalized by angiographic intervention.
topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: A 14-year-old male adolescent with a known history of asymptomatic antithrombin deficiency (ATD), diagnosed at the age of six, presented to the emergency department with subfebrile temperatures for 1 week and localized pain in his right popliteal fossa for 3 days. He had been immobilized for several days following a minor sports injury. His mother was also diagnosed with ATD and recently, with inferior vena cava atresia (IVCA). After admission, he exhibited markedly elevated D-dimers and C-reactive protein levels and reduced antithrombin activity. Vascular ultrasound confirmed thrombosis in the right lower extremity. Consequently, he was treated with continuous infusion of unfractionated heparin and antithrombin substitution. However, the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) showed an insufficient response to heparin treatment, so the anticoagulative therapy was switched to direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban. Despite the treatment, MRI later revealed extended thromboses in both lower extremities and thrombosis of both iliac vessels, and occlusion of the inferior vena cava (IVC). Catheter-directed local thrombolysis was performed, but re-thrombosis occurred in both the right and left pelvic axis and the right lower extremity, leading to a second hospital admission and re-induction of therapy with both intravenous antithrombin and catheter-directed thrombolysis. The patient was discharged from the hospital on phenprocoumon, an oral anticoagulant, with a new target International Normalized Ratio (INR) of 2.5–3.0 in order to prevent re-thrombosis.What was the treatment approach for a 14-year-old male with antithrombin deficiency who presented with thrombosis in his lower extremities and iliac vessels?
options: {'A': 'The patient was treated with antithrombin substitution without any other anticoagulant', 'B': 'The patient was treated with catheter-directed local thrombolysis without any other anticoagulant', 'C': 'The patient was treated with direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban without any other intervention', 'D': 'The patient was discharged on an oral anticoagulant, phenprocoumon, without any prior anticoagulant therapy', 'E': 'The patient was initially treated with unfractionated heparin and antithrombin substitution. Due to an insufficient response, the therapy was switched to direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban. Despite these treatments, extended thromboses occurred, leading to the use of catheter-directed local thrombolysis. The patient was eventually discharged on an oral anticoagulant, phenprocoumon, to prevent re-thrombosis.', 'F': 'The patient was treated with a combination of unfractionated heparin and direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban but no other interventions were made', 'G': 'The patient was only treated with unfractionated heparin'}
answer: The patient was initially treated with unfractionated heparin and antithrombin substitution. Due to an insufficient response, the therapy was switched to direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban. Despite these treatments, extended thromboses occurred, leading to the use of catheter-directed local thrombolysis. The patient was eventually discharged on an oral anticoagulant, phenprocoumon, to prevent re-thrombosis.

question: A 14-year-old male with a known history of asymptomatic antithrombin deficiency (ATD) presented to the emergency department with symptoms of subfebrile temperatures for a week and pain in his right popliteal fossa for three days. He had been immobilized for several days due to a minor sports injury prior to the onset of these symptoms. Laboratory tests revealed elevated D-dimers and C-reactive protein. Given the symptoms and the patient's history of ATD, there was a high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).Which imaging modality would be the first choice to confirm suspected deep vein thrombosis in this patient?
options: {'A': 'lower extremity x-ray', 'B': 'scan', 'C': 'vascular ultrasound', 'D': 'd-dimer blood test', 'E': 'computed tomography (', 'F': 'test', 'G': 'magnetic resonance imaging (', 'H': 'complete blood count ('}

clinical_note:
A 35-year-old man presented with the complaints of low back ache for 12 years, radiating to right leg for 4 months and numbness extending to lateral side of the sole of right foot. On examination, there was a 30% sensory loss in right S1 dermatome as compared with contralateral limb, with no bladder bowel involvement. Patient had no motor deficit. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbosacral spine was suggestive of IM cystic lesion at L2-3 hypointense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2-weighted images. MRI brain did not reveal any abnormality. Lumbar puncture and serologic studies were not performed.
With the differential diagnosis of neoplastic lesion, the patient was taken up for posterior laminectomy. L2-3 laminectomy was done. A dural bulge was identified. On durotomy, the cord was found to be enlarged. Under microscopic guidance, posterior longitudinal myelotomy was done, the cysts were approached, and subtotal resection of cysts was done. Intraoperatively, three grayish white cysts were identified. Cysts were found to be adherent to the nerve roots causing their inflammation. As a result, one of the cysts could not be excised and was only decompressed. The remaining two cysts were completely excised. Histopathology revealed it to be NCC.
The patient improved postoperatively. Back pain was relieved, and there was significant reduction in radiating pain. He was started on albendazole (15 mg/kg body weight) for 4 weeks and steroids for 2 weeks. The patient was discharged on the 4th post-operative day. He was followed-up biweekly for the first month. Thereafter, monthly follow-up was done for the next 2 months. MRI done at 6 months confirmed resolution of the cystic lesion. Thereafter, 6 monthly follow-up was done. Patient is symptom free and not on any medication at 2 years of follow-up.

question: A 35-year-old male patient came in with a long-standing complaint of lower back pain, which had been radiating to his right leg for the last few months. He also reported numbness in his right foot. A neurological examination revealed a sensory deficit in the right S1 dermatome. MRI of his lumbosacral spine revealed a cystic lesion at L2-L3. Surgical intervention led to the identification and partial excision of multiple cysts. The patient was diagnosed with Neurocysticercosis (NCC) based on histopathology reports.What important aspect of the patient's lifestyle history should be explored, given his diagnosed condition?
options: {'A': 'consumption of undercooked or contaminated pork', 'B': 'regular exposure to industrial waste', 'C': 'chronic smoking habit', 'D': 'consumption of a high-sodium diet', 'E': 'frequent alcohol consumption'}
answer: consumption of undercooked or contaminated pork

question: A 35-year-old male patient presented with chronic low back pain, which had begun to radiate to his right leg and was associated with numbness in his foot. The physical exam showed sensory loss in the right S1 dermatome without motor deficits or bladder bowel involvement. Lumbosacral spine MRI revealed an intramedullary cystic lesion at L2-3. The patient underwent surgical management, resulting in the removal of cysts adhering to nerve roots. The histopathological evaluation determined the cysts to be neurocysticercosis. Postoperatively, the patient's symptoms improved significantly and he was managed with albendazole and steroids. Follow-up at six months with MRI showed resolution of the cystic lesion.Given the patient's diagnosis and management, which laboratory finding would most likely be observed?
options: {'A': 'polycythemia', 'B': 'thrombocytosis', 'C': 'eosinophilia', 'D': 'hyperkalemia', 'E': 'leukocytosis'}

clinical_note:
An 88-year-old woman (height, 150 cm; weight, 41 kg) with no history of drug allergy or general anesthesia was scheduled for transfemoral TAVI because of severe aortic stenosis (AS). The surgery was performed under general anesthesia to facilitate the use of transesophageal echocardiography and to manage any intraoperative complications. She was taking 0.625 mg/day bisoprolol, a selective β-1 blocker, for hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation. Additionally, she was taking amlodipine for hypertension. Preoperative transthoracic echocardiography showed severe AS (aortic valve peak flow velocity: 4.73 m/s; mean aortic valve pressure gradient: 47 mmHg; aortic valve area: 0.41 cm2) and myocardial hypertrophy (left ventricular posterior wall thickness and interventricular septum thickness: 14 mm).
Pre-anesthetic medication for sedation was not administered. She received bisoprolol and amlodipine 3 h before entering the operating room. Figure shows the anesthesia record. General anesthesia was induced using midazolam and remifentanil; additionally, rocuronium was administered to facilitate tracheal intubation. She received total intravenous anesthesia: continuous infusions of propofol and remifentanil. Noradrenaline and dopamine were infused continuously through the central venous catheter to maintain blood pressure. AS disappeared after valve implantation. During the surgery, complete atrioventricular block occurred, and ventricular pacing (VVI mode: 60 ppm) was initiated. No other complications were associated with the surgical procedure. Postoperatively, she received 100 mg sugammadex through the central venous catheter, but 2 min later, her systolic arterial blood pressure (ABP) decreased unexpectedly to less than 40 mmHg. Simultaneously, ventilator monitoring revealed elevated peak and plateau airway pressures (60 and 40 cmH2O, respectively). No skin rash was observed on the body surface. Transthoracic echocardiography showed underfilling of the left ventricle without right ventricular dilatation or pericardial effusion. No abnormalities were observed in left ventricular wall motion.
The patient developed distributive shock, which was clinically diagnosed as anaphylactic shock caused by sugammadex because of the rapid onset of severe hypotension and bronchospasm. First, two boluses of 0.05 mg adrenaline were administered through the central venous catheter, followed by rapid volume resuscitation using crystalloid (1 L infusion within 30 min). The dose of noradrenaline was increased to 0.3 μg/kg/min. Consequently, the airway pressures returned to the original level, but the hypotension persisted. Thereafter, adrenaline was administered via bolus (0.1 mg twice) and continuous infusion (0.1 μg/kg/min); however, the increase in her ABP was minimal. Therefore, 1 mg glucagon was administered intravenously, and her systolic ABP immediately rose to 130 mmHg. An erythematous rash also appeared on her neck with the increase in ABP. Her general condition was stable after the therapeutic interventions. Ventricular pacing was continued because bradycardia with complete atrioventricular block was persistent during the interventions. She was admitted to the intensive care unit under tracheal intubation. Subsequently, the continuous infusion of adrenaline was discontinued, and the continuous infusion of noradrenaline was reduced. We also administered 125 mg methylprednisolone for 3 days. She was extubated 9 h after the onset of anaphylaxis, and circulatory agonists were discontinued the following day. She was discharged without complications on postoperative day 9. Blood tests revealed a total serum tryptase level of 7.3 ng/mL and 1.2 ng/mL at 1 h and 24 h after onset, respectively. We advised the patient to undergo allergy tests, such as skin prick tests or intradermal tests, to identify the cause of anaphylaxis. However, the patient refused these tests because she was elderly and unlikely to undergo surgery under general anesthesia in the future.
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report. This report was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Nagasaki University Hospital (Approval number: 21041932).
topic: underlying processes/pathways
question: An 88-year-old woman with severe aortic stenosis underwent a transfemoral Transcatheter Aortic Valve Implantation procedure. Postoperatively, she was given sugammadex and experienced a sudden drop in systolic arterial blood pressure and elevated peak and plateau airway pressures. Echocardiography showed no right ventricular dilatation or pericardial effusion and normal left ventricular wall motion. She was clinically diagnosed with anaphylactic shock, suspected to be caused by sugammadex. Despite interventions using adrenaline, fluid resuscitation, and increased noradrenaline dosage, her blood pressure remained low. Only after the administration of 1 mg glucagon intravenously did her systolic arterial blood pressure rise to normal levels. She also developed an erythematous rash on her neck during this time.Based on the patient's clinical presentation and response to treatment, which underlying process most likely caused the anaphylactic shock in this case?
options: {'A': 'hypersensitivity reaction to sugammadex', 'B': 'adverse effect of noradrenaline', 'C': 'reaction to general anesthesia', 'D': 'adverse effect of dopamine', 'E': 'adverse effect of glucagon'}

topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: An elderly woman with severe aortic stenosis underwent a surgical procedure for valve implantation. Post-surgery, she was administered sugammadex, which led to a sudden decrease in her systolic arterial blood pressure and an increase in airway pressures. These are symptoms of distributive shock, suspected to be an anaphylactic reaction to sugammadex. This was treated with adrenaline and glucagon, resulting in stabilization of the patient's condition.What was the suspected cause of the patient's distributive shock following a valve implantation procedure, and how was it managed?
options: {'A': "the patient's distributive shock was suspected to be an anaphylactic reaction to sugammadex, and it was managed with the administration of adrenaline and glucagon.", 'B': 'the distributive shock was caused by an unexpected reaction to the valve implant, and it was managed by removing the implant.', 'C': 'the distributive shock was a complication of the valve implantation procedure, and it was managed with corrective surgery.', 'D': "the patient's distributive shock was a side effect of her pre-existing medication, bisoprolol, and it was managed by adjusting the dosage of this medication.", 'E': "the patient's distributive shock was caused by a reaction to the anesthesia used during the procedure, and it was managed with additional doses of the same anesthesia."}
answer: the patient's distributive shock was suspected to be an anaphylactic reaction to sugammadex, and it was managed with the administration of adrenaline and glucagon.

clinical_note:
An 88-year-old woman (height, 150 cm; weight, 41 kg) with no history of drug allergy or general anesthesia was scheduled for transfemoral TAVI because of severe aortic stenosis (AS). The surgery was performed under general anesthesia to facilitate the use of transesophageal echocardiography and to manage any intraoperative complications. She was taking 0.625 mg/day bisoprolol, a selective β-1 blocker, for hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation. Additionally, she was taking amlodipine for hypertension. Preoperative transthoracic echocardiography showed severe AS (aortic valve peak flow velocity: 4.73 m/s; mean aortic valve pressure gradient: 47 mmHg; aortic valve area: 0.41 cm2) and myocardial hypertrophy (left ventricular posterior wall thickness and interventricular septum thickness: 14 mm).
Pre-anesthetic medication for sedation was not administered. She received bisoprolol and amlodipine 3 h before entering the operating room. Figure shows the anesthesia record. General anesthesia was induced using midazolam and remifentanil; additionally, rocuronium was administered to facilitate tracheal intubation. She received total intravenous anesthesia: continuous infusions of propofol and remifentanil. Noradrenaline and dopamine were infused continuously through the central venous catheter to maintain blood pressure. AS disappeared after valve implantation. During the surgery, complete atrioventricular block occurred, and ventricular pacing (VVI mode: 60 ppm) was initiated. No other complications were associated with the surgical procedure. Postoperatively, she received 100 mg sugammadex through the central venous catheter, but 2 min later, her systolic arterial blood pressure (ABP) decreased unexpectedly to less than 40 mmHg. Simultaneously, ventilator monitoring revealed elevated peak and plateau airway pressures (60 and 40 cmH2O, respectively). No skin rash was observed on the body surface. Transthoracic echocardiography showed underfilling of the left ventricle without right ventricular dilatation or pericardial effusion. No abnormalities were observed in left ventricular wall motion.
The patient developed distributive shock, which was clinically diagnosed as anaphylactic shock caused by sugammadex because of the rapid onset of severe hypotension and bronchospasm. First, two boluses of 0.05 mg adrenaline were administered through the central venous catheter, followed by rapid volume resuscitation using crystalloid (1 L infusion within 30 min). The dose of noradrenaline was increased to 0.3 μg/kg/min. Consequently, the airway pressures returned to the original level, but the hypotension persisted. Thereafter, adrenaline was administered via bolus (0.1 mg twice) and continuous infusion (0.1 μg/kg/min); however, the increase in her ABP was minimal. Therefore, 1 mg glucagon was administered intravenously, and her systolic ABP immediately rose to 130 mmHg. An erythematous rash also appeared on her neck with the increase in ABP. Her general condition was stable after the therapeutic interventions. Ventricular pacing was continued because bradycardia with complete atrioventricular block was persistent during the interventions. She was admitted to the intensive care unit under tracheal intubation. Subsequently, the continuous infusion of adrenaline was discontinued, and the continuous infusion of noradrenaline was reduced. We also administered 125 mg methylprednisolone for 3 days. She was extubated 9 h after the onset of anaphylaxis, and circulatory agonists were discontinued the following day. She was discharged without complications on postoperative day 9. Blood tests revealed a total serum tryptase level of 7.3 ng/mL and 1.2 ng/mL at 1 h and 24 h after onset, respectively. We advised the patient to undergo allergy tests, such as skin prick tests or intradermal tests, to identify the cause of anaphylaxis. However, the patient refused these tests because she was elderly and unlikely to undergo surgery under general anesthesia in the future.
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report. This report was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Nagasaki University Hospital (Approval number: 21041932).
keypoint: rapid onset of severe hypotension and bronchospasm due to anaphylactic shock

question: An 88-year-old woman with aortic stenosis was scheduled for a surgical procedure. During the surgery, she received a medication known as sugammadex. Soon after, her blood pressure dropped significantly and her airway pressures increased. Despite receiving a variety of treatments, her blood pressure remained low. This sudden onset of severe symptoms led to a diagnosis of anaphylactic shock.What significant symptoms did the patient exhibit that led to a diagnosis of anaphylactic shock?
options: {'A': 'severe hypertension and decreased airway pressures', 'B': 'severe hypertension and increased airway pressures', 'C': 'mild hypotension and decreased airway pressures', 'D': 'severe hypotension and increased airway pressures', 'E': 'mild hypotension and increased airway pressures'}
answer: severe hypotension and increased airway pressures

question: An 88-year-old woman with severe aortic stenosis and no history of drug allergy was scheduled for transfemoral Transcatheter Aortic Valve Implantation (TAVI). She was under bisoprolol and amlodipine for hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation. Preoperative transthoracic echocardiography showed severe aortic stenosis and myocardial hypertrophy. General anesthesia was induced using midazolam and remifentanil; additionally, rocuronium was used for tracheal intubation. She received continuous infusions of propofol and remifentanil, and Noradrenaline and dopamine were used to maintain blood pressure. During the surgery, complete atrioventricular block occurred. Postoperatively, she received 100 mg sugammadex, but then her systolic arterial blood pressure (ABP) plummeted to less than 40 mmHg. Also, ventilator monitoring revealed elevated peak and plateau airway pressures. Transthoracic echocardiography showed underfilling of the left ventricle without right ventricular dilatation or pericardial effusion. The patient was diagnosed with distributive shock, suspected to be caused by an allergic reaction to sugammadex. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient's hypotension persisted. The administration of 1 mg glucagon resulted in a rise in her systolic ABP to 130 mmHg. Following the therapeutic interventions, her general condition stabilized. She was extubated 9 hours after the onset of the anaphylactic reaction, and circulatory agonists were discontinued the following day. She was discharged without complications on postoperative day 9. Blood tests revealed a total serum tryptase level of 7.3 ng/mL and 1.2 ng/mL at 1 h and 24 h after onset, respectively. The patient was advised to undergo allergy tests, but she refused due to her age and unlikelihood of future surgeries under general anesthesia.Based on the transthoracic echocardiography results and the patient's symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis for the 88-year-old woman who experienced a sudden drop in blood pressure postoperatively?
options: {'A': 'Distributive shock', 'B': 'Aortic dissection', 'C': 'Cardiogenic shock', 'D': 'Myocardial infarction', 'E': 'Pulmonary embolism'}

question: An 88-year-old woman with severe aortic stenosis and chronic atrial fibrillation underwent a transfemoral Transcatheter Aortic Valve Implantation (TAVI). Immediately after the procedure, she experienced a sudden drop in blood pressure and elevated airway pressures. Despite rapid administration of adrenaline and noradrenaline, the patient's condition did not improve. Only after the administration of intravenous glucagon did her blood pressure return to normal levels.What is the most likely diagnosis for the patient's postoperative condition?
options: {'A': 'hypovolemic shock', 'B': 'cardiogenic shock', 'C': 'septic shock', 'D': 'anaphylactic shock', 'E': 'neurogenic shock'}

clinical_note:
A previously healthy 49-year-old female with a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and body mass index (BMI) of 30.37 kg/m2 presented to the emergency department with altered mental status, abdominal pain, hematemesis, and hypotension. According to family, the patient complained of abdominal pain earlier that morning and was later found at home minimally responsive and recurrently vomiting blood.
In the emergency department, the patient’s vitals included a blood pressure of 94/50 mmHg, a temperature of 87.1 Fahrenheit, and a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute. The patient was intubated for airway protection. She received 5L of fluid as well as one unit of packed red blood cells for suspected large fluid volume loss. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed and was remarkable for a Mallory-Weiss tear with portohypertensive gastropathy. This was thought to be caused by the repeated vomiting reported by her family. CT scan showed peripancreatic edema and fat stranding, consistent with acute pancreatitis (Figure ). A repeat CT scan was done to evaluate the progression of her pancreatitis, which showed worsening pancreatitis with developing ascites. Labs were remarkable for a glucose up to 955 mg/dL, hemoglobin A1c (HgbA1c) of 13.7%, and a triglyceride level up to 1608 mg/dL (Table ). The patient was then placed on an insulin drip for her significantly elevated blood glucose. After her glucose normalized, she was continued on an insulin drip until her triglycerides dropped below 500 mg/dL. The patient was then downgraded to the general medical floor and discharged after being able to tolerate a regular diet without significant pain or discomfort.
topic: recognizes associated conditions of a disease
question: A 49-year-old female with a history of well-controlled hypertension and a BMI of 30.37 kg/m2 presented to the emergency department with symptoms of altered mental status, abdominal pain, and hematemesis. She was also hypotensive upon arrival. Family members reported that she had been complaining of abdominal pain earlier that day and was later found at home in a minimally responsive state, vomiting blood repeatedly. In the emergency department, she was intubated for airway protection and received fluids and a unit of packed red blood cells due to suspected large fluid volume loss. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a Mallory-Weiss tear and portohypertensive gastropathy, likely caused by the reported repeated vomiting. In addition, a CT scan indicated acute pancreatitis with worsening signs and developing ascites. Remarkably, her lab results showed an extremely high glucose level, increased HgbA1c, and a significantly elevated triglyceride level. She was treated with an insulin drip until her blood glucose and triglyceride levels normalized. She was eventually discharged after she was able to tolerate a regular diet without significant pain or discomfort.What are the possible complications associated with a Mallory-Weiss tear and portohypertensive gastropathy in a patient with high glucose and triglyceride levels?
options: {'A': 'Progression to chronic pancreatitis', 'B': 'Onset of acute coronary syndrome', 'C': 'Development of cirrhosis and liver failure', 'D': 'Development of esophageal varices and variceal bleeding', 'E': 'Development of hepatic encephalopathy', 'F': 'Onset of acute renal failure due to dehydration', 'G': 'Possible complications include aspiration pneumonia due to vomiting and altered mental status, further gastrointestinal bleeding, and worsening of pancreatitis due to elevated triglyceride levels. Additionally, the high glucose levels could lead to diabetic ketoacidosis.'}
answer: Possible complications include aspiration pneumonia due to vomiting and altered mental status, further gastrointestinal bleeding, and worsening of pancreatitis due to elevated triglyceride levels. Additionally, the high glucose levels could lead to diabetic ketoacidosis.

question: A 49-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension and obesity was admitted to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, altered mental status, and recurrent episodes of vomiting blood. Despite receiving large volumes of fluids and packed red blood cells, her condition remained critical. Investigations conducted, including an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and a CT scan, revealed a Mallory-Weiss tear and acute pancreatitis, respectively. Lab results indicated abnormal levels of glucose, HgbA1c, and triglycerides. A specific treatment strategy was initiated to manage her significantly elevated triglyceride levels.What therapeutic intervention was employed for the management of this patient's acute pancreatitis triggered by hypertriglyceridemia?
options: {'A': 'administration of antihypertensive medications only', 'B': 'aggressive fluid resuscitation alone', 'C': 'initiation of an insulin drip until triglyceride levels decrease to below 500 mg/dl', 'D': 'immediate surgical intervention', 'E': 'immediate prescription of a low-fat diet'}
answer: initiation of an insulin drip until triglyceride levels decrease to below 500 mg/dl

question: A 49-year-old female with a history of hypertension and obesity presented to the emergency department with altered mental status, abdominal pain, hematemesis, and hypotension. The patient was found at home in a minimally responsive state, vomiting blood. Upon arrival in the emergency department, she had a low blood pressure, low temperature, and a high respiratory rate. The patient was intubated and received fluids and packed red blood cells for assumed large fluid volume loss. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a Mallory-Weiss tear with portohypertensive gastropathy, likely caused by the repeated vomiting. A CT scan indicated acute pancreatitis. Lab results highlighted extremely high glucose levels, a high HgbA1c, and a high triglyceride level. The patient was placed on an insulin drip to manage her glucose levels, and once stabilized, was downgraded to the general medical floor. With this in mind, the immediate management or priority in managing the patient's actively bleeding Mallory-Weiss tears needs to be addressed.What is the immediate management strategy for a patient with actively bleeding Mallory-Weiss tears?
options: {'A': 'Endoscopic hemostasis', 'B': 'Intravenous fluid resuscitation', 'C': 'Administration of a proton pump inhibitor', 'D': 'Blood transfusion', 'E': 'Immediate surgery'}

clinical_note:
A 22-year-old male presented in the emergency department with acute onset of swelling and redness over the right side of the neck and chest wall for the last three days. He had features of septicemia such as drowsiness or Glasgow Coma Scale score of 11/15, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, pulse rate of 130 beats per minute, blood pressure of 84/56 mmHg, and urine output of 15 mL/hour. He had no history of chronic disease, drug reaction, trauma, unknown bite, or significant familial disease. Blood investigations revealed low hemoglobin of 7.6 g/dL, raise leukocyte count of 28000/mm3, low albumin of 2.2 g/dL, raised serum creatinine of 2.23 mg/dL, serum urea of 174 mg/dL, and low sodium of 125 mEq/L. Serological markers including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (95 mm/hour) and procalcitonin (25.2 ng/mL) were higher. X-ray of the chest was grossly normal (Figure ), and contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck revealed irregular, well-defined, hypodense, non-enhancing area in the right parotid gland with extension into the neck spaces, larynx, and subcutaneous planes (Figure ). CECT of the chest revealed mild effusion in bilateral pleural space secondary to acute infection and no evidence of lymphadenopathy or osteomyelitis (Figures , ).
Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining from pleural fluid was negative for acid-fast bacillus (AFB bacilli). The patient was managed in the intensive care unit with ventilator support due to acute respiratory distress syndrome. He was diagnosed with acute progressive necrotizing fasciitis with multiple organ dysfunction syndromes due to an unknown cause of septicemia. He underwent multiple aggressive debridements of the neck and chest wall (Figure ).
The cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) and ZN staining revealed positive mycobacteria and AFB bacilli for pathological tissue. Therefore, the pus collected in the parotid region and neck space was likely secondary to tubercular infection. A split-thickness graft was applied in multiple fractions after three weeks of anti-tubercular chemotherapy. The patient had a long hospital stay due to the difficult location and complexity of the ulcer over the neck. He was followed up for six months in good clinical condition after discharge.
topic: the cause/infectious agent or predisposing factor(s)
question: A 22-year-old male came to the emergency department with acute onset of swelling and redness over the right side of the neck and chest wall. He had no history of chronic disease, drug reaction, trauma, unknown bite, or significant familial disease. Laboratory tests revealed multiple abnormalities, and imaging showed an irregular, hypodense, non-enhancing area in the right parotid gland. Despite initial negative results for acid-fast bacillus (AFB), subsequent tests on pathological tissue were positive for a specific type of bacteria.Which bacteria was identified in the patient's pathological tissue that may have contributed to his condition?
options: {'A': 'pseudomonas aeruginosa', 'B': 'escherichia coli', 'C': 'staphylococcus aureus', 'D': 'mycobacteria and acid-fast bacillus (afb)', 'E': 'streptococcus pyogenes'}

question: A 22-year-old male presented to the emergency department with acute swelling and redness over his right neck and chest. He was experiencing symptoms of septicemia, including drowsiness, rapid breathing and pulse, low blood pressure, and reduced urine output. Laboratory results indicated anemia, an elevated white cell count, and signs of kidney impairment. Imaging revealed a hypodense area in the right parotid gland extending to the neck, larynx, and subcutaneous planes, and a mild effusion in the bilateral pleural space. The patient was diagnosed with acute progressive necrotizing fasciitis and multiple organ dysfunction syndromes due to an unknown cause of septicemia. Testing on the pathological tissue revealed positive mycobacteria and acid-fast bacilli, indicative of a tuberculosis infection.What is the primary pathophysiological process involved in a tuberculosis infection?
options: {'A': 'uncontrolled cell proliferation', 'B': 'formation of granulomas', 'C': 'excessive neutrophil accumulation', 'D': 'excessive collagen production', 'E': 'overactive complement system'}

topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: A 22-year-old male arrived at the emergency department displaying acute swelling and redness over his right side of the neck and chest. He had a high pulse rate, low blood pressure, and a low urine output, indicating septicemia. His blood tests revealed low hemoglobin, a high leukocyte count, and raised serum creatinine, among other abnormalities. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck and chest showed a hypodense, non-enhancing area in the right parotid gland and mild bilateral pleural effusion. His condition rapidly deteriorated, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome and his subsequent admission to the intensive care unit. Further testing revealed the presence of mycobacteria and AFB bacilli in tissue samples.Based on the presence of mycobacteria and AFB bacilli in tissue samples, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
options: {'A': 'staphylococcus aureus infection', 'B': 'tuberculosis', 'C': 'candida albicans infection', 'D': 'escherichia coli infection', 'E': 'streptococcus pyogenes infection', 'F': 'pseudomonas aeruginosa infection'}

clinical_note:
A 41-year-old Japanese woman presented to our clinic with a 4 month history of bilateral groin pain and right buttock pain. Her right hip was more painful than her left hip. There was no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. Her medical history included iron-deficiency anemia diagnosed 2 years earlier, after which she had been on iron supplements. She had no fracture episodes, including fragility fractures.
Her height, body weight, and body mass index were 155 cm, 42 kg, and 18.7 kg/m2, respectively. She was able to walk for approximately 10 minutes without a stick, albeit at a slow speed. Limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint were observed thus: flexion, 100°, internal rotation 5°, external rotation 15°, and abduction 20°, on both sides. She was able to perform a straight-leg raise of the right limb with substantial pain. The neurovascular status of both lower extremities was intact. The Japanese Orthopaedic Association scoring system for the evaluation of hip-joint function (JOA hip score) was 46 points for her right hip and 56 points for her left hip. The score was based on a total of 100 points, comprising 40 for pain, 20 for range of motion, 20 for the ability to walk, and 20 for activities of daily living [].
Standard radiographs of both hips (Fig. a–c) demonstrated no characteristic findings such as the crescent sign, sclerotic band pattern, and collapse of the femoral head, and no joint space narrowing was seen in either femoral head. MRI of both hips (Fig. d, e) presented a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head in the T1 weighted image and high signal region in almost all of the femoral head in the short tau inversion recovery (STIR). The oblique axial views of the proton density-weighted image showed a low-signal sinuous line in the anteromedial region of the femoral head (Fig. ). Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) values were low in both femoral necks. Bone mineral density was 0.909 g/cm2 (T-score –0.9, Z-score −0.8) in the lumbar spine, 0.594 g/cm2 (T-score −1.8, Z-score −1.4) in the right femoral neck, and 0.529 g/cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.0) in the left femoral neck. Laboratory findings were as follows: C-reactive protein (CRP) 0.03 mg/dl (normal range: 0–0.5 mg/dl); alkaline phosphatase 608 IU/l (40–150 IU/l); calcium 9.0 mg/dl (8.4–10.2 mg/dl); albumin 4.4 g/d (3.9–4.9 g/d); and hemoglobin 9.7 g/dl (12–16 g/dl). Bone turnover markers were as follows: tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b (TRACP-5b) 463 mU/dl (premenopausal normal range: 120–420 mU/dl) and total procollagen type 1 N-terminal propeptide (Total P1NP) 72.7 ng/ml (26.4–98.2 ng/ml). We diagnosed bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and classified it as stage 1 in both femoral heads, according to the Association Research Circulation Osseous (ARCO) classification [].
The patient was instructed not to take as much weight as possible using sticks on the right side. Her symptoms improved immediately. However, 6 months later, her symptoms increased slightly without any traumatic episodes. Radiographic findings indicated almost no change (Fig. a–c). However, a slight signal change in the medial subcapital region was observed in the MRI scan (Fig. d, e). Her pain gradually increased thereafter, and 10 months after her first visit, walking became difficult. The JOA hip score decreased to 34 points in both hips; still, no changes could be observed in the radiograph (Fig. a–c). MRI of both hips showed a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks, with bone marrow edema around the fracture (Fig. d, e). Because the cause of the fractures was not identified, the DEXA and bone turnover markers were measured again, and 25-hydroxy (OH) vitamin D was measured for the first time. All DEXA values decreased. The bone mineral density was 0.849 g/cm2 (T-score −1.5, Z-score −1.2) in the lumbar spine, 0.527 g/ cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.1) in the right femoral neck, and 0.490 g/cm2 (T-score −2.7, Z-score −2.4) in the left femoral neck. TRACP-5b level increased to 607 mU/dl, and total P1NP decreased to 52.7 ng/ml. Her 25(OH) vitamin D level was 11.1 ng/dL and she was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency. Based on the above results, our diagnosis was bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The patient underwent internal fixation of both hips with sliding hip screws (Dual SC screw system; Kisco, Kobe, Japan) to stabilize the stress fractures. In addition, the reaming performed before inserting of the sliding hip screw served as core decompression for the femoral heads [, ]. The specimens obtained from the reaming were examined histologically. Definitive findings of osteonecrosis such as bone marrow necrosis and loss of osteocyte nuclei in the femoral heads were observed (Fig. ). Postoperative radiographs showed no evidence of displacement of the fractures (Fig. ). We administered eldecalcitol 0.75 μg per day orally for vitamin D deficiency, and daily subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate. In the immediate postoperative period, the patient began to bear weight as tolerated with the use of an assistive device bilaterally. One month postoperatively, she was able to walk without pain and used a cane part time. She eventually regained full walking ability without a cane 3 months after surgery. Furthermore, her JOA hip score improved to 90 points in both hip joints at 5 months after surgery. Radiographs showed no evidence of recurrent stress fracture in the femoral neck or progression of osteonecrosis (Fig. ). Sequential oblique axial MRI showed that the necrotic region of the femoral head had decreased 5 months after surgery (Fig. ).
topic: underlying processes/pathways
question: A 41-year-old Japanese woman with a history of iron-deficiency anemia presented with a 4 month history of bilateral groin pain, which was more severe on the right side. She reported no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. She was observed to have limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint and experienced substantial pain during a straight-leg raise of her right limb. Radiographs of both hips showed no characteristic findings, and MRI images demonstrated a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) values were low in both femoral necks. Laboratory findings indicated a normal C-reactive protein level, increased alkaline phosphatase, normal calcium and albumin, and decreased hemoglobin. Bone turnover markers were increased. The patient was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Over the subsequent months, the patient's condition deteriorated, and she was diagnosed with bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Following treatment, which included internal fixation of both hips, vitamin D supplementation, and subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate, the patient was able to regain full walking ability and her hip score improved significantly.What are the underlying processes and pathways involved in the regulation of bone remodeling in the context of osteonecrosis and stress fractures of the femoral head?
options: {'A': 'Treatments such as vitamin D supplementation and teriparatide acetate have no role in regulating bone remodeling.', 'B': 'The regulation of bone remodeling involves the balance between bone resorption by osteoclasts and bone formation by osteoblasts. In osteonecrosis and stress fractures, this balance is disrupted, leading to increased bone resorption and decreased bone formation. This can be influenced by factors such as decreased blood supply, inflammation, and changes in hormonal levels. Treatments like vitamin D supplementation and teriparatide acetate work by promoting bone formation and reducing bone resorption.', 'C': 'The process involves primarily the action of chondrocytes in cartilage formation.', 'D': 'The condition is caused by increased bone formation and decreased bone resorption.', 'E': 'Bone remodeling is mainly regulated by the actions of osteocytes alone.'}
answer: The regulation of bone remodeling involves the balance between bone resorption by osteoclasts and bone formation by osteoblasts. In osteonecrosis and stress fractures, this balance is disrupted, leading to increased bone resorption and decreased bone formation. This can be influenced by factors such as decreased blood supply, inflammation, and changes in hormonal levels. Treatments like vitamin D supplementation and teriparatide acetate work by promoting bone formation and reducing bone resorption.

topic: mechanisms, drugs
question: A 41-year-old woman presented to the clinic with bilateral groin pain and right buttock pain that had persisted for four months. The pain was more severe in her right hip. She had a history of iron-deficiency anemia and was on iron supplements. No evidence of trauma or substance misuse was noted. Her hip radiographs and MRI showed no significant abnormalities, but her DEXA values were low. Lab tests revealed a low vitamin D level.Based on the available clinical information, what was the primary diagnosis for this patient and how was it managed?
options: {'A': 'the patient was diagnosed with stress fractures in the femoral necks and underwent intramedullary nailing, along with parathyroid hormone treatment for her vitamin d deficiency.', 'B': 'the patient was diagnosed with hip dysplasia and underwent physical therapy and calcitonin treatment.', 'C': 'the patient was diagnosed with hip bursitis and treated with corticosteroid injections and bisphosphonates to manage her vitamin d deficiency.', 'D': 'the patient was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and treated with internal fixation of both hips and eldecalcitol for her vitamin d deficiency.', 'E': 'the patient was diagnosed with bilateral hip arthritis and underwent total hip arthroplasty and was prescribed vitamin d supplements.'}
answer: the patient was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and treated with internal fixation of both hips and eldecalcitol for her vitamin d deficiency.

topic: knows individual’s risk factors for development of condition
question: A 41-year-old woman with a history of iron-deficiency anemia came in with bilateral groin and right buttock pain. She had no history of trauma, alcohol abuse, or steroid use. Her mobility was limited due to pain, and her bone mineral density was found to be lower than normal in both femoral necks. She was diagnosed with bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head.Based on the patient's history and current condition, which factors might have contributed to her reduced bone density?
options: {'A': 'steroid use and smoking', 'B': 'trauma and high-impact sports', 'C': 'iron-deficiency anemia, limited mobility due to bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head, and existing low bone mineral density.', 'D': 'heavy alcohol use and obesity', 'E': 'hypertension and diabetes.'}
answer: iron-deficiency anemia, limited mobility due to bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head, and existing low bone mineral density.

clinical_note:

Limitations in the passive motion of her bilateral hip joint were observed thus: flexion, 100°, internal rotation 5°, external rotation 15°, and abduction 20°, on both sides. She was able to perform a straight-leg raise of the right limb with substantial pain. The neurovascular status of both lower extremities was intact. The Japanese Orthopaedic Association scoring system for the evaluation of hip-joint function (JOA hip score) was 46 points for her right hip and 56 points for her left hip. The score was based on a total of 100 points, comprising 40 for pain, 20 for range of motion, 20 for the ability to walk, and 20 for activities of daily living [].
Standard radiographs of both hips (Fig. a–c) demonstrated no characteristic findings such as the crescent sign, sclerotic band pattern, and collapse of the femoral head, and no joint space narrowing was seen in either femoral head. MRI of both hips (Fig. d, e) presented a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head in the T1 weighted image and high signal region in almost all of the femoral head in the short tau inversion recovery (STIR). The oblique axial views of the proton density-weighted image showed a low-signal sinuous line in the anteromedial region of the femoral head (Fig. ). Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) values were low in both femoral necks. Bone mineral density was 0.909 g/cm2 (T-score –0.9, Z-score −0.8) in the lumbar spine, 0.594 g/cm2 (T-score −1.8, Z-score −1.4) in the right femoral neck, and 0.529 g/cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.0) in the left femoral neck. Laboratory findings were as follows: C-reactive protein (CRP) 0.03 mg/dl (normal range: 0–0.5 mg/dl); alkaline phosphatase 608 IU/l (40–150 IU/l); calcium 9.0 mg/dl (8.4–10.2 mg/dl); albumin 4.4 g/d (3.9–4.9 g/d); and hemoglobin 9.7 g/dl (12–16 g/dl). Bone turnover markers were as follows: tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b (TRACP-5b) 463 mU/dl (premenopausal normal range: 120–420 mU/dl) and total procollagen type 1 N-terminal propeptide (Total P1NP) 72.7 ng/ml (26.4–98.2 ng/ml). We diagnosed bilateral osteonecrosis of the femoral head and classified it as stage 1 in both femoral heads, according to the Association Research Circulation Osseous (ARCO) classification [].
The patient was instructed not to take as much weight as possible using sticks on the right side. Her symptoms improved immediately. However, 6 months later, her symptoms increased slightly without any traumatic episodes. Radiographic findings indicated almost no change (Fig. a–c). However, a slight signal change in the medial subcapital region was observed in the MRI scan (Fig. d, e). Her pain gradually increased thereafter, and 10 months after her first visit, walking became difficult. The JOA hip score decreased to 34 points in both hips; still, no changes could be observed in the radiograph (Fig. a–c). MRI of both hips showed a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks, with bone marrow edema around the fracture (Fig. d, e). Because the cause of the fractures was not identified, the DEXA and bone turnover markers were measured again, and 25-hydroxy (OH) vitamin D was measured for the first time. All DEXA values decreased. The bone mineral density was 0.849 g/cm2 (T-score −1.5, Z-score −1.2) in the lumbar spine, 0.527 g/ cm2 (T-score −2.4, Z-score −2.1) in the right femoral neck, and 0.490 g/cm2 (T-score −2.7, Z-score −2.4) in the left femoral neck. TRACP-5b level increased to 607 mU/dl, and total P1NP decreased to 52.7 ng/ml. Her 25(OH) vitamin D level was 11.1 ng/dL and she was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency. Based on the above results, our diagnosis was bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The patient underwent internal fixation of both hips with sliding hip screws (Dual SC screw system; Kisco, Kobe, Japan) to stabilize the stress fractures. In addition, the reaming performed before inserting of the sliding hip screw served as core decompression for the femoral heads [, ]. The specimens obtained from the reaming were examined histologically. Definitive findings of osteonecrosis such as bone marrow necrosis and loss of osteocyte nuclei in the femoral heads were observed (Fig. ). Postoperative radiographs showed no evidence of displacement of the fractures (Fig. ). We administered eldecalcitol 0.75 μg per day orally for vitamin D deficiency, and daily subcutaneous injections of teriparatide acetate. In the immediate postoperative period, the patient began to bear weight as tolerated with the use of an assistive device bilaterally. One month postoperatively, she was able to walk without pain and used a cane part time. She eventually regained full walking ability without a cane 3 months after surgery. Furthermore, her JOA hip score improved to 90 points in both hip joints at 5 months after surgery. Radiographs showed no evidence of recurrent stress fracture in the femoral neck or progression of osteonecrosis (Fig. ). Sequential oblique axial MRI showed that the necrotic region of the femoral head had decreased 5 months after surgery (Fig. ).

question: A 41-year-old woman, with no history of trauma or substance abuse, presented with bilateral groin and right buttock pain that had been persisting for the past four months. Physical examination revealed limitations in passive motion of her bilateral hip joint. Radiographs of her hips did not reveal any characteristic findings. However, MRI of both hips showed a low signal line in the subchondral region of the femoral head and a high signal region in almost the entirety of the femoral head. Despite initial symptom improvement, her condition worsened over six months, with an MRI revealing a nondisplaced subcapital fracture on the medial side of both femoral necks and surrounding bone marrow edema. The patient was diagnosed with bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck secondary to a suspected condition.What is the most probable condition that led to the bilateral stress fracture of the femoral neck in this patient?
options: {'A': 'femoroacetabular impingement', 'B': 'hip dysplasia', 'C': 'osteonecrosis of the femoral head', 'D': 'osteoarthritis', 'E': 'osteoporosis'}

clinical_note:
A 72-year-old male, known hypertensive on medication, non-smoker, no family history of cancer presented with complaints of pain in the right hip with difficulty in walking in January 2019. On evaluation, a pathological fracture was found at the neck of the right femur. Magnetic resonance imaging of the spine was done, which revealed osteophyte complexes at C3-C4, C4-C5, C5-C6 vertebrae causing narrowing of neural foramina. Multiple T2-hyperintense lesions in lung parenchyma were an incidental finding. Upon further evaluation with positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) scan of the whole body, mass in the apex of the right lung, right hilum, mediastinal lymph node, soft tissue wall thickening in the proximal stomach along with multiple liver and bone metastases were found. Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy revealed a proximal gastric growth from which a biopsy was taken. Histopathology showed poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. A provisional diagnosis of carcinoma stomach with distant metastasis was reached. But immunohistochemistry came out to be positive for thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and cytokeratin-7 (CK-7), while negative for cytokeratin 20 (CK-20) (Figures -).
So, a possibility of metastasis from a lung primary was considered. It was confirmed by a biopsy from the lung mass that revealed adenocarcinoma as the histopathology. On immunohistochemistry, it was positive for TTF-1 and CK-7 while negative for CK-20 and synaptophysin. Analysis for anaplastic lymphoma kinase, epidermal growth factor receptor, and receptor tyrosine kinase 1 were all negative but programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) tumor proportion score (TPS) was 90%. So, the final diagnosis was adenocarcinoma lung with multiple lung, liver, femur, as well as gastric metastases.
For the pathological fracture, he underwent fixation by intramedullary nailing followed by palliative external beam radiotherapy 8 Gy in a single fraction. He received 10 three-weekly cycles each of Inj. pembrolizumab 200 mg as intravenous infusion and Inj. denosumab 120 mg subcutaneously from March 2019 to September 2019. An interim PET-CT scan done after four cycles of immunotherapy in June 2019 showed a near-complete metabolic response (Figures -).
After 10 cycles, Inj. pembrolizumab was discontinued as the patient was unwilling to continue due to personal reasons. He was then started with chemotherapy, Inj. pemetrexed 500 mg/m2 and Inj. bevacizumab 15 mg/kg in October 2019. Following this, the patient developed grade 1 maculopapular rash, pedal edema, and grade 2 diarrhea, which were managed conservatively. After that the patient did not opt for the continuation of chemotherapy. The next visit of the patient was in February 2021 with complaints of cough and breathlessness. On re-evaluation with PET-CT scan, progressive disease was found in the primary site (Figures , ).
Palliative radiotherapy of 30 Gy in 10 fractions to the primary lesion was delivered through anteroposterior and posteroanterior portals of 10 megavolt energy each in April 2021 via linear accelerator (Elekta-Versa HD) which was tolerated well (Figure ).
In June, the patient developed an altered sensorium and contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging of brain revealed multiple brain metastases for which the patient received palliative whole-brain radiotherapy of 30 Gy in 10 fractions over two weeks from the same linear accelerator. His condition further deteriorated, and in July, the patient succumbed to disease progression.
topic: interprets laboratory or other study findings
question: A 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension presented with right hip pain and difficulty walking. An evaluation revealed a pathological fracture at the neck of the right femur. MRI of the spine showed osteophyte complexes at C3-C4, C4-C5, C5-C6 vertebrae causing narrowing of neural foramina, and incidental findings of multiple T2-hyperintense lesions in lung parenchyma. A whole-body PET-CT scan detected a mass in the apex of the right lung, right hilum, mediastinal lymph node, soft tissue wall thickening in the proximal stomach, and multiple liver and bone metastases. An endoscopy revealed a proximal gastric growth and the biopsy was suggestive of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemistry was positive for thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and cytokeratin-7 (CK-7), leading to the consideration of metastasis from a lung primary. This was confirmed by a biopsy from the lung mass which also showed adenocarcinoma positive for TTF-1 and CK-7. The patient was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung with multiple metastases and treated with immunotherapy and chemotherapy. Re-evaluation after a year revealed disease progression. The patient subsequently developed multiple brain metastases and received palliative radiotherapy. His condition deteriorated, and he succumbed to disease progression.What does a positive result for thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and cytokeratin-7 (CK-7) in an immunohistochemistry test indicate in a patient with adenocarcinoma lung?
options: {'A': 'It suggests the presence of a benign lung tumor.', 'B': 'It indicates the presence of gastric primary in metastatic adenocarcinoma.', 'C': 'It indicates the patient has a non-invasive form of lung cancer.', 'D': 'It suggests the presence of a thyroid primary in metastatic adenocarcinoma.', 'E': 'It indicates the presence of liver primary in metastatic adenocarcinoma.', 'F': 'It indicates the presence of lung primary in metastatic adenocarcinoma.'}
answer: It indicates the presence of lung primary in metastatic adenocarcinoma.

clinical_note:
A 90-year-old male was found in his home slumped to his right side and unable to be awakened. Paramedics calculated an 8/15 Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, which remained the same on admission. On presentation to the hospital, the patient had left facial droop, bilateral pinpoint pupils, and right-sided weakness. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score on admission was 26, suggesting a severe stroke. All other observations on admission were non-revealing, including vital signs, biochemical tests, and systems review.
The patient’s neurological medical history included two previous transient ischemic attacks and suspected dementia. Other past medical history included chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, adult polycystic kidney disease, hypercholesterolemia, and aortic valve sclerosis. He was an ex-smoker of unknown pack-years and prior to admission was living independently.
Initial head CT performed only showed chronic small vessel disease with periventricular leukoaraiosis, consistent with his age. Thrombolysis was initiated with an intravenous tissue-plasminogen activator, however, the patient’s GCS declined to 6/15 approximately 40 minutes after the start of thrombolysis. A repeat head CT was performed, again showing no acute findings. To prevent further deterioration, a decision to monitor the patient’s condition conservatively was made.
Over the next few days, the patient remained very somnolent. When the patient was able to awaken, he was only capable of responding to simple commands. Speech and language therapists noted that fatigue was limiting conversations, with the patient speaking with imprecise articulation and at a low volume. Occupational therapists concurred that the patient was poorly engaged during sessions, while physiotherapists classified this patient as having limited rehabilitation potential.
Stroke was finally confirmed upon a third head CT several days after admission, which showed bilateral thalamic infarcts. Other findings included hyperdensity at the basilar tip and left posterior cerebral artery, likely due to wall calcification of vessels. An MRI revealed bilateral hyperintensities in the thalami, consistent with acute bilateral thalamic stroke, with small left parietal cortical infarction (Figure ).
Imaging also confirmed the arterial location of the infarction, a single branch of the pre-communicating (P1) segment of the left posterior cerebral artery known as the artery of Percheron (AOP). Over the next month, the patient participated in multidisciplinary rehabilitation sessions. He had a gradual return of physical function and with it, his sense of humor returned, much to the delight of his family and the attending staff. He was unable to care for himself independently and was eventually discharged to a care home. Six months later, he was mobile with a walking stick and had a reasonable quality of life. One year after the initial presentation to the hospital, he passed away from an intercurrent chest infection.
topic: underlying anatomic structure or physical location
question: A 90-year-old male was found unresponsive at home with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8/15. He had a history of transient ischemic attacks and suspected dementia among other comorbidities. Upon hospital admission, he presented with neurological symptoms including left facial droop, bilateral pinpoint pupils, and right-sided weakness. His National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score suggested a severe stroke. Imaging studies, including multiple head CT scans and an MRI, revealed bilateral thalamic infarcts and a small left parietal cortical infarction.Based on the patient's clinical presentation and imaging findings, where is the stroke most likely located?
options: {'A': 'middle cerebral artery', 'B': 'basilar artery', 'C': 'posterior cerebral artery', 'D': 'artery of percheron (aop)', 'E': 'anterior cerebral artery'}

question: A 90-year-old male was admitted to the hospital after being found unresponsive at home, with an initial Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8/15. The patient exhibited left facial droop, bilateral pinpoint pupils, and right-sided weakness. His National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score on admission was 26, indicating a severe stroke. His medical history included two previous transient ischemic attacks, suspected dementia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, adult polycystic kidney disease, hypercholesterolemia, and aortic valve sclerosis. Initial head CT showed chronic small vessel disease with periventricular leukoaraiosis. Despite thrombolysis initiated with an intravenous tissue-plasminogen activator, the patient's condition deteriorated. A repeat head CT showed no acute findings and a decision was made to monitor the patient’s condition conservatively. A third head CT several days later confirmed stroke, showing bilateral thalamic infarcts. An MRI revealed bilateral hyperintensities in the thalami, consistent with acute bilateral thalamic stroke, with small left parietal cortical infarction. The arterial location of the infarction was confirmed as the artery of Percheron (AOP). The patient underwent a month of multidisciplinary rehabilitation, had a gradual return of physical function, and was eventually discharged to a care home.What role did the tissue-plasminogen activator play in the treatment of the 90-year-old male patient who suffered from an acute bilateral thalamic stroke?
options: {'A': 'The tissue-plasminogen activator was used for thrombolysis in the treatment of the acute bilateral thalamic stroke.', 'B': "The tissue-plasminogen activator was used to treat the patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.", 'C': "The tissue-plasminogen activator was used for dialysis in the patient's chronic kidney disease.", 'D': "The tissue-plasminogen activator was used to alleviate the patient's suspected dementia symptoms.", 'E': "The tissue-plasminogen activator was used to regulate the patient's blood pressure."}
answer: The tissue-plasminogen activator was used for thrombolysis in the treatment of the acute bilateral thalamic stroke.

question: A 90-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after being found unresponsive at his home. options: {'A': "the patient's history of transient ischemic attacks, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia are likely contributing factors to his bilateral thalamic infarcts.", 'B': "the patient's history of adult polycystic kidney disease and suspected dementia.", 'C': 'the patient had no significant medical history that could contribute to bilateral thalamic infarcts.', 'D': 'the patient was an ex-smoker with an unknown pack-year history.', 'E': "the patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and abdominal aortic aneurysm repair."}
answer: the patient's history of transient ischemic attacks, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia are likely contributing factors to his bilateral thalamic infarcts.
